sense.def: used when the person speaking or writing is the subject of the verb
dictionaryExamples: I love you.
Did I tell you about my vacation?
I'm not late, am I?
I'd like some coffee.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't understand much English. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Lithuanian

sense.def: water that has frozen and become solid
dictionaryExamples: Gerry slipped on the ice and broke his arm.
The pond was covered in ice all winter.
Would you like ice in your juice?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [It's fun] when you slide on the ice. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: to make people feel more relaxed in a social situation
dictionaryExamples: I told everyone a joke, which helped to break the ice.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And, of course, don't forget that a warm smile is one of the best ways to break the ice. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a very large piece of ice in the coldest waters of the ocean
dictionaryExamples: The ship hit an iceberg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another animal you cannot miss is the Humboldt p[e]nguin - you can see thousands of them [all] over an iceberg. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

blocks.phrase: be the tip of the iceberg

sense.def: to be a small part of a very big problem
dictionaryExamples: We've corrected a few errors, but they're just the tip of the iceberg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He racked his brain trying to remember where he might have left it and finally reali[z]ed that his problems were just a tip of the iceberg, if her mother knew about the loss. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a sweet, frozen food made from milk or cream, sugar, and a flavor
dictionaryExamples: chocolate/vanilla/strawberry ice cream
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like chocolate and ice cream with fruit. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: the game of hockey
dictionaryExamples: He loves ice hockey.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like watching ice hockey, because I play this game too. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: the activity or sport of moving across ice using ice skates
dictionaryExamples: We're going ice skating.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year, I went ice-skating with some friends and it was not as easy as I thought it would be, but I liked it anyway. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a small picture on a computer screen that you choose in order to make the computer do something
dictionaryExamples: Click on the print icon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He clicked on the icon on the screen which started the operation. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a person or thing that is famous because it represents a particular idea or way of life
dictionaryExamples: He's a musical innovator and cultural icon.
a music/fashion icon
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think he is still very famous because he is an icon and kickboxing is still very popular because of him. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: covered in ice
dictionaryExamples: icy roads
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had fallen off it on an icy street and had got injured. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: extremely cold
dictionaryExamples: an icy wind
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Fast as [the] wind, she was falling down and down, until her long thin finger touched the icy cold water. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: without showing any emotion
dictionaryExamples: an icy stare
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: FOGG is the typical rich English man: cold with a[n] icy heart, uncommunicative. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an official document that shows or proves who you are
dictionaryExamples: Make sure you carry some ID with you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please could you check if you [have] it because it contains my ID. Key English Test; A2; French

sense.def: a card that shows your name, photograph, and information to prove who you are
dictionaryExamples: You will need a passport or an ID card.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last night I left my ID card in your house. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: a suggestion or plan
dictionaryExamples: a bad/brilliant/great/stupid idea
"Let's go swimming." "That's a good idea!"
If you have any ideas for what I can get Josh, let me know.
It was Kate's idea to rent a car.
I have an idea - why don't we go to the beach?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nick, it's a wonderful idea! Key English Test; A2; Czech

sense.def: to not know
dictionaryExamples: "Where's George?" "I have no idea."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have no idea about how his children are. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: an opinion or belief
dictionaryExamples: We have very different ideas about the environment.
Leach presents the idea that it is impossible to spoil a child.
I'm not a singer - where did you get that idea?
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Have you change[d] your ideas after the exhibition about the future of your town? 
 Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: an understanding, thought or picture in your mind
dictionaryExamples: Do you have any idea what he looks like?
Can you give me an idea of the cost?
I don't like the idea of living so far away from my family.
I've got a pretty good idea why they left early.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For children it's great to get an idea of how these "big" animals eat, drink and live. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the aim or purpose of something
dictionaryExamples: The idea is to give the students a chance to voice their opinions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was the idea behind this new product: although made in New Zealand, the new product would have its name, packag[ing], marketing and advertising support in keeping with the Russian traditions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: the principle of something
dictionaryExamples: We all admire the idea of dignity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many of us sit there with watery eyes, as we're moved by the idea of unification, equality and brotherhood among the different nations of the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to emphasize that you do not know something
dictionaryExamples: I haven't the faintest idea what you're talking about.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some twenty years ago, when I left my parents' home to go and live on my own, I was [given] four mugs. By whom? I haven't the faintest idea. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: perfect, or the best possible
dictionaryExamples: the ideal job
She's the ideal person for the job.
This small table is ideal for bedroom your kitchen.
It's the ideal opportunity to meet people.
In an ideal world no one would go hungry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The market on Wednesday is an ideal occasion to meet and photograph the local people. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: believing that it is possible to achieve very good things, even when others do not think this is likely
dictionaryExamples: When I was young and idealistic, I believed it was possible to change the world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Carolina has conquered the world, not only through her impressive results but through her appearance in front of the cameras, her idealistic ideas and her constantly happy mood. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: in a perfect way
dictionaryExamples: She seemed ideally suited for the job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I believe I am ideally suited for this job. First Certificate in English; B2; Pass

sense.def: used to talk about how something would be in a perfect situation
dictionaryExamples: Ideally, I'd like to work at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Ideally, through this camp, I would like to teach Japanese songs and dance to them and I would also like to learn about their culture. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: exactly the same
dictionaryExamples: I've got three identical blue suits.
The two rooms were virtually identical.
The tests are identical to  last year's.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have identical tastes which is pretty unusual, I think, particularly in adults. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: an official document that shows or proves who you are
dictionaryExamples: We were asked to show some identification before the security guards would let us in.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's important to send my wallet back as I can't withdraw money from my account without any proof of identification. Key English Test; A2; Shona

sense.def: when you recognize and can name someone or something
dictionaryExamples:
Identification of the victims of
 the plane crash still is not complete.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [In the home of the future,] we might even be using voice identification and fingerprints instead of keys. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to recognize someone or something and say or prove who or what they are
dictionaryExamples: Even the smallest baby can identify its mother by her voice.
Our teacher could identify every student after only two days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mainly for children, zoos teach them many things about animals; for instance, their habits, their relationship [to] each other and the original propose: to know many kinds of animals and identify them. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to find a particular thing or all the things of a particular group
dictionaryExamples: You need to identify your priorities.
The research will be used to identify training needs.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The purpose of this report is to identify which lessons or other activities should be filmed. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: to feel that you are similar to someone, and can understand them or their situation because of this
dictionaryExamples: Readers can easily identify with the hero's sense of frustration at the beginning of the novel.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Orwell give[s] the animals human characteristics and we can identify with them. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: who someone is
dictionaryExamples: to hide/protect your identity
to prove/reveal your identity
The witness was given a new identity for her protection.
The newspaper photo apparently showed him in Rome but it was a case of mistaken identity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But this idea fell through when the real Martine revealed her identity. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: the things that make one person or group of people different from others
dictionaryExamples: cultural/national identity
I think my job gives me a sense of identity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were many people and many speakers who talked about all sorts of subject[s] such as politics, religion, gender identity, [and] art. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: a group of words used together with a meaning that you cannot guess from the meanings of the separate words
dictionaryExamples: To "bite off more than you can chew" is an idiom that means to try to do something that is too difficult for you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [Greek] has many verbs, adjectives and idioms and the grammar can be very complicated. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a stupid person or someone who is behaving in a stupid way
dictionaryExamples: Some idiot left the faucet on in the bathroom and there's water everywhere.
I felt like such an idiot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Everybody was treating me like a big idiot. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: not working or not doing anything
dictionaryExamples: It was break time and both the machines and the workers sat idle.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I saw some people from the group wandering here and there in Pic[c]adilly Circus & Street, but most of them were sitting idle in their rooms watching TV or just spending their time in the hotel bar or restaurant. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: not serious or having no real purpose
dictionaryExamples: idle chatter/speculation
This is no idle threat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, as soon as it became a plan of action rather than an idle thought, it began to grow on her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: someone who you admire and respect very much
dictionaryExamples: Baseball players were his childhood idols.
a teen/pop idol
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The reason for the choice is that it was the time when Bill Gates, my idol, started his business and when people began to use computers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: a statue or picture that represents a god, which people pray to as part of their religion
dictionaryExamples: H has a small stone idol of a Hindu deity.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Buddha idols stand in row[s] protected by glass cases. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: used to say that something will happen only after something else happens or is true
dictionaryExamples: We'll have the party on the deck if the weather's good.
If anyone calls while I'm out, please take a message.

We’ll deal with
 that problem if and when it arises.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you want [me] to, I'll bring you some of my CDs. Key English Test; A2; Swiss German

sense.def: used to say what the situation will be if something does not happen
dictionaryExamples: I hope to see you there but, if not, I'll call you.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm going to paint my bedroom with the pink paint. Remember to put on your old cloth[e]s. If not, your clothes will become pinky and you can't use them anymore. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: used when you offer someone something
dictionaryExamples: If you like, I could drive you there.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you like, we can go to a night club. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: used to mean always or every time
dictionaryExamples: If water is heated to 212°F it turns to steam.
If I don't get enough sleep I get a headache.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If I think it's pretty, I buy it. Preliminary English Test; B1; French

sense.def: used to talk about something that might happen
dictionaryExamples: If I won the lottery, I'd buy a boat.
What would you do if he moved away?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be great if you came to the city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: whether
dictionaryExamples: I wonder if he'll get the job?
Mrs. Kramer called a half hour ago to ask if her cake was ready.
I don't care if he likes it or not - I'm coming!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But let's see if a friend can lend me his notebook, so that way I will c[a]t[ch] up easily. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used when you give someone advice
dictionaryExamples: I think I'd take the job if I were you.
If I were you, I'd probably go.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But you enjoy clubbing and discos, so, if I were you, I would [choose the] city. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: used to say you wish for something or you wish something was so
dictionaryExamples:
If only I had more
 money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If only I had been more careful. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: used to talk about what would/might/could, etc. have happened
dictionaryExamples: If we had the money, we'd get a new car.
If you'd mentioned this earlier, it might not have been necessary to call the doctor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If she had gone home by taxi, she would have not risked her life. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: used when you want to say how doing something simple would make it possible to avoid something unpleasant
dictionaryExamples:
If only she'd listened to me, she
 wouldn’t be in this mess.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Therefor[e] I think that if only the zoo owners take good care of the animals, they won't suffer if they are locked up. 
 First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: if this is the case
dictionaryExamples: It might rain this afternoon, and if so, we'll have to have the party indoors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let me know if you [can] come, and if so, [whether] you prefer the 15th or 22nd of February. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: used to describe how a situation seems to be
dictionaryExamples: It looks as if it's going to rain.
It was as if  we had been friends for years.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sun was up in the sky, there were no clouds and it looked as if it was going to be a wonderful day. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: said when you are giving your opinion
dictionaryExamples: If you ask me, you should take that job.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you ask me, I don't think that TV can replace books. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: if it is necessary
dictionaryExamples:
If need
 be, we can take two cars.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: On the one hand I won't indulge my children's whims and I will lecture them or punish them if need be. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when someone does not have enough knowledge, understanding, or information about something
dictionaryExamples: There is widespread ignorance about how disease spreads.
I was shocked by her total ignorance of world history.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, living in ignorance about the history and the origins of things that one is surrounded with is like showing disrespect to those who helped to create the modern world as it is known today. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not having enough knowledge, understanding, or information about something
dictionaryExamples: He was a newcomer to Formula One and ignorant of many of the circuits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is often claimed by scientists that people's modern lifestyle has resulted in this plight our world is facing and that unfortunately people are either ignorant of it or indifferent. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to pay no attention to something or someone
dictionaryExamples: I smiled at her but she just ignored me.
They ignored our warnings.

The mayor ignored the hecklers and went on with her
 speech.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Paul ignored it at first and continued his shopping but the dog kept following him. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: not feeling well, or suffering from a disease
dictionaryExamples: He is in the hospital,  critically ill.
I felt ill so I went home.
He's been ill.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to make some phone calls home because my brother was a little ill, but I would like to pay you for them. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: bad
dictionaryExamples: He suffered no ill effects from his fall.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Working long hours can have ill effects on the health. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: feeling anxious and not relaxed
dictionaryExamples: He looked ill at ease in the room full of reporters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was a bit annoyed, or rather, ill at ease at first; but his kindness soon made me feel relaxed in his company. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: not allowed by law
dictionaryExamples: Fireworks are illegal in many states.
It is illegal to drive a car without a license.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although he has a very charming personality, he uses it to take part in illegal activities and he has been in trouble with the law several times. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is not allowed by law
dictionaryExamples: They entered the country illegally.
an illegally parked car
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was afraid and bought a gun illegally. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: not able to read or write
dictionaryExamples: Most of the children are illiterate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is well known that many European charity workers travel to developing countries in order to educate illiterate children or to rebuild ruined villages. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: a disease of the body or mind
dictionaryExamples: He died at home after a long illness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's because my aunt has a terrible illness and I have to go and see her. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: when you are ill
dictionaryExamples: She had five days off work due to illness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was a little paper on the door which informed us that the restaurant was closed due to illness. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: an idea or belief that is not true
dictionaryExamples: He had no illusions about his talents as a singer.

I was under the
 illusion that trains ran frequently on weekends.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just one detail turning out to be not as expected or not perfect is often enough to shatter their illusions and cause arguing. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: something that is not really as it appears to be
dictionaryExamples: There is a large mirror at one end to create the illusion of more space.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This architectural solution creates an illusion of space, one may feel as inside a vast hall. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to add pictures to something such as a book or magazine
dictionaryExamples:
She writes children’s books and also
 
 illustrates them.
The book is beautifully illustrated by the author.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last year I illustrated two children's books by H. J. Simons. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to give information through diagrams, lists of numbers, etc.
dictionaryExamples: This process is illustrated in the diagram below.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The pie chart illustrates the primary causes of agricultural land becoming less productive worldwide. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to give more information or examples to explain or prove something
dictionaryExamples:
To illustrate her point,
 
 she told a story about how her family felt when they moved here.
The speaker illustrated his thesis with three case studies.
She used recordings to illustrate how the music has been interpreted by different artists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, the careers that were presented illustrated very well the possibilities in the selected fields. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: a drawing, painting, photograph, or other picture
dictionaryExamples: Look at the illustration on page 37.
And there's a charming illustration of four cups of coffee.
color/black and white illustrations
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you read about that period of time in history books and see pictures and illustrations, you can almost "feel" the atmosphere and sense the power the Monarc[h]y po[ss]es[s]ed at the time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: an example that explains or proves something
dictionaryExamples: This delay is a perfect illustration of why we need a new computer system.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And it seems to me that this difference inevitably affects not only the range of food[s] which are available in those countries but also their appearances: a good illustration of this is probably the case of French cuisine which is always served in a decorative way on beautiful plates. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: the way that other people think someone or something is
dictionaryExamples: He wants to improve his public image.

She is trying to
 project a more presidential image.
At the time, many people had a negative image of all performers, even opera singers.
Better communicating our high standards has improved the image of our school among college applicants.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, I do not think that there are many things to do for Turin, but what I said before could really improve the image of our wonderful town. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: a picture, especially on film or television or in a mirror
dictionaryExamples: a digital/satellite/video image
The baby caught sight of her image in the mirror.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On [the] one hand, the first obvious advantage of watching television is that it shows us images, for example, that do not appear in the books, like a movie. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a picture in your mind or an idea of how someone or something is
dictionaryExamples: I have an image in my mind of the way I want the garden to look.
For me  this song always conjures up images of  Caribbean beaches.
The poem is full of images of new life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It conjures up images of brightly lit and decorated malls, big stores, little stores proudly showing off their wares. International English Language Testing System; C2; Marathi

sense.def: not real but imagined in your mind
dictionaryExamples: The story takes place in an imaginary world.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mickey Mouse [...] describes stories that can happen to humans whereas Spong[e] Bob lives in an imaginary world underwater. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the part of your mind that creates ideas or pictures of things that are not real or that you have not seen
dictionaryExamples: There's nothing out here - it's just your imagination.

Rafael has a very vivid
 imagination.
For some reason the story captured imagination of the public.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I thought it was my imagination, because it was very late and the concert had been so long. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: the ability to create ideas or pictures in your mind
dictionaryExamples: The job needs someone with creativity and imagination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Endless imagination and [the] development of technology will lead us to future fashion. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to make someone very excited or interested in something
dictionaryExamples: His paintings really fired my imagination.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The newspaper article on education that I read really fired my imagination and urged me to think about the points raised. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: new or clever and often unusual
dictionaryExamples: an imaginative use of color
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her imaginative stories are very popular with children of all ages. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: able to create new and interesting ideas or things
dictionaryExamples:
He's a very
 imaginative little boy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is a very imaginative girl and she always invents new games for our children, so that they have never felt bored in her presence. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to form an idea or picture of something in your mind
dictionaryExamples: Imagine Bob when he was young - that's what John looks like.
Imagine (that) you're eating an ice cream - try to feel how cold it is.
She imagined herself sitting in her favorite armchair back home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Just imagine the sun, the sea and all that fun on the beach. Preliminary English Test; B1; Serbian

sense.def: to have an idea of what something is like or might be like
dictionaryExamples: Imagine how it feels to be away from home for the first time.
I can't imagine going anywhere in this rain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can't imagine how tired I am. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to think that you hear or see something that does not really exist
dictionaryExamples: "Did you hear a noise?" "No, you're imagining things."
I don't hear anything - you must be imagining it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I turn[ed] back but I didn't [see] anyone, so I thought that I had imagined it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to guess that something is probably true or real
dictionaryExamples: I imagine they charge extra for dessert.
I don't imagine (that) they can visits for more than a day or two.
"Will they change it?" "I imagine so."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I imagine that the watch is in your bedroom. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: to copy the way someone or something looks, sounds, or behaves
dictionaryExamples:
My four-year-old
 daughter is always trying to imitate her older sister.
He imitated her accent perfectly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although not all celebrities are so altruistic, it is true that those who take action stimulate their followers to imitate them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: a copy of something that is made to look like the real thing
dictionaryExamples: It wasn't a genuine designer handbag, just a cheap imitation.
imitation leather/fur
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The word spread out so fast that the vast majority of people ended up purchasing genuine Versace jeans or even cheap imitations just to catch up with the fashion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: behaving in a way that is childish and not in the emotionally well-developed way people expect from someone your age
dictionaryExamples: Some of the kids are so immature - they're always doing silly things and don't pay attention.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You might regard me as an immature, seventeen-year-old girl for I like decorating my diary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: happening or done without delay or very soon after something else
dictionaryExamples: The directors have demanded his immediate resignation.
The change in school hours will have little effect on most families.

He made an immediate impact when he arrived to coach the
 team.

Regular bus service may not be available  in the  immediate
 aftermath of the hurricane.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you will give this matter your immediate attention. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: important now and needing attention
dictionaryExamples: We have no immediate plans.
Our immediate concern is getting food and water to the refugees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It can't be an immediate objective, of course, but we mustn't give up. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: closest to  something or someone
dictionaryExamples:
There are stores, movie theaters, parks, schools - all
 right in the immediate area.
Members of your immediate family will receive invitations to the graduation ceremonies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first place, there are beautiful landscapes in the immediate vicinity of both hotels. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: now or without waiting or thinking about something
dictionaryExamples: We really ought to leave immediately.
The purpose of the meeting wasn't immediately obvious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Can you send me it immediately? Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: next to something, or close to something in time
dictionaryExamples: Milton Street is on the left, immediately after the bank.
They moved in immediately before classes began.
We heard a loud crash from the room immediately above us.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Tickets are on the ground floor, immediately to your right when you have entered the building. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: extremely large
dictionaryExamples: This computer can store an immense amount of data.
The marble columns outside the palace are immense.
immense poser/wealth/talent
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Another reason for the immense popularity of shopping as a leisure activity is economics. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: extremely
dictionaryExamples: Country music is immensely popular.
immensely talented/powerful/successful

sense.def: someone who comes to live in a different country
dictionaryExamples:
My grandparents arrived here as immigrants from Russia in
 
 1910.
legal/illegal/new immigrants

sense.def: the place where people's official documents are checked when they enter a country at an airport, port, border, etc.
dictionaryExamples: After you've been through immigration (control), you can go and get your luggage.
immigration officers

sense.def: when someone comes to live in a different country
dictionaryExamples: immigration policy
There are strict limits on immigration (into the country).

sense.def: coming or happening very soon
dictionaryExamples:
A rain storm
 was imminent.
imminent danger

dictionaryExamples: immoral behavior

sense.def: living or lasting forever

sense.def: famous or remembered for a very long time
dictionaryExamples: In Yogi Barra's immortal words: "You can observe a lot by watching."

sense.def: not affected by a particular type of behavior or emotion

dictionaryExamples: Healthy eating will help boost your immune system.

sense.def: the effect that a person, event or situation has on someone or something
dictionaryExamples:

The environmental impact of

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could live without watching TV, but it would make a serious impact on my life. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the force or action of one object hitting another

sense.def: to affect something or someone
dictionaryExamples: Rising interest rates are sure to impact (on) the housing market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Those extra calories, the fat and salt in our food and the decrease in vitamin rich food, impacts on our health. International English Language Testing System; C1; German

sense.def: when someone is impatient
dictionaryExamples: His impatience was obvious.

sense.def: easily annoyed by someone's mistakes or because you have to wait
dictionaryExamples: He's a good teacher, but he can be impatient with slow learners.

Don’t be so impatient, you’ll get your
 turn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hours passed and she became impatient and thought he had forgotten about their date. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: wanting something to happen as soon as possible
dictionaryExamples: He's got a lot of exciting ideas and he's impatient to get started.

sense.def: the form of a verb which is usually used for giving orders
dictionaryExamples: In the phrase "Leave him alone," the verb "leave" is an imperative/is in the imperative.

sense.def: When an action or process is imperative, it is extremely important that it happens or is done.
dictionaryExamples: It is imperative (that) I speak with him at once.

sense.def: not perfect and with some mistakes

sense.def: not showing any interest or feeling

sense.def: to make an idea, system, law, plan, etc., start to happen or operate

sense.def: a result or effect that seems likely in the future

legal/financial implications

sense.def: a suggestion of something that you make without saying it directly

sense.def: the involvement of someone with something bad
dictionaryExamples: His career was ruined by his implication in the financial scandal.

sense.def: suggested but not stated directly

sense.def:
to involve
 something as a necessary part or condition
dictionaryExamples: Democracy implies free elections.

sense.def: used to show that the name of something tells you something about it
dictionaryExamples: A "suggested price" is, as the name implies, the sale price suggested by the manufacturer.

sense.def: not polite
dictionaryExamples: It is impolite to point at people.

sense.def: to buy or bring in products from another country

sense.def: a product that is imported from another country
dictionaryExamples: food/oil imports

Imports of foreign cars are at an
 
 all-time high.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: In my opinion, one of the reasons for these changes is that our country bec[a]me wealthier after World War II, which led to [an] increase in food import[s]. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: the activity of importing something into a country
dictionaryExamples: The FDA oversees the import of seafood, fruits, and vegetables.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of them, which is the most important for a government, is the import of foreign money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: valuable, useful or necessary

The important thing is to keep the heat low or the sugar will burn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is not important for me. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

an important person/decision

sense.def: in a way that is important
dictionaryExamples:
She has a pleasant personality, but more importantly, she is well
 qualified for the job.

dictionaryExamples:
It’s almost impossible to

It seems impossible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I tried to find it but it was impossible! Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: very difficult to deal with
dictionaryExamples:
Traffic at rush hour is just
 impossible.

sense.def: to cause someone to admire or respect you
dictionaryExamples:
She impressed us with her
 sincerity.

I get the impression
 that he’s rather shy.

I was under the impression that you didn’t like your
 job.

Is Mark still in bed?

My daughter's in
                      the hospital overnight.

sense.def: forming a part of something

dictionaryExamples: Do you recognize that man in the grey suit?

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [T]he man has to be dressed in black. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

dictionaryExamples: The car in front suddenly stopped and I ran into the back of it.

sense.def: liking someone very much and having romantic or sexual feelings for them
dictionaryExamples: Have you ever been in love?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I am in love with him. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: experiencing an emotion or condition
dictionaryExamples: She's in a bad/good mood this morning.
You're in great danger.
He's living in luxury in the south of France.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope you are in a good mood today, because we are planning to go to Cinepolis. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: arranged or divided in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: We all sat down in a circle.
The desks were arranged in rows of ten.
Discounts are available to people traveling in large groups.
The books on these shelves are arranged in alphabetical order.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We often work in groups where we can talk in English. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swiss German

sense.def: as well (as)
dictionaryExamples: In addition to his flat in London, he has a villa in Italy and a castle in Scotland.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm really sorry that I didn't write back earlier, but to make up for this I will answer your questions in detail! Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: beginning from now

sense.def: usually, or in most situations

In general, the weather here stays sunny.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In general I like reading in my free[ ]time, when I have nothing to do... Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: crying
dictionaryExamples: I found him in tears in his bedroom.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By the end of it, Mary Anne was nearly in tears. Preliminary English Test; B1; Bengali

blocks.phrase: in order (for sb/sth) to do sth

sense.def: with the purpose of achieving something
dictionaryExamples: He came home early in order to see the children before they went to bed.
She worked all summer in order to save enough money.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She will go to the United States in order to improve her English. Preliminary English Test; B1; Catalan

sense.def: expressed or written in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: They spoke in Russian the whole time.

Complete the form in (black) ink.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I also speak in English during the break. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: especially
dictionaryExamples: Are you looking for anything in particular?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've read a lot of books recently, and in particular I liked: "Eleven minutes" and "Veronica decides to die", written by Paulo Coelho. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: involved or connected with a particular subject or activity
dictionaryExamples: a degree in philosophy
advances in medical science

sense.def: because of a possibility of something happening, being needed, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I don't think I'll need any money but I'll bring some just in case.

sense.def: when something happens, or in preparation for when something happens
dictionaryExamples: We keep a bucket of water backstage, in case of fire.

sense.def: considering the whole of someone or something, and not just a particular part of them

dictionaryExamples: Most people are in favor of reducing traffic in cities.

Divide the dough in half and roll it out into two circles.

sense.def: used to emphasize what is really true, or to give more information
dictionaryExamples: I thought she was Portuguese, but in actual fact she's Brazilian.

sense.def: used to give another reason for something you are saying, or that you have done
dictionaryExamples: I don't want to go and in any case, I haven't been invited.

sense.def: because of the mentioned situation
dictionaryExamples: There's no coffee left? In that case I'll have tea.

sense.def: used to show the total amount of something
dictionaryExamples: Some of the children came, so there were 15 of us in all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, even though most people like[d] [the] group RADIANT, they [only] played for 35 minutes in all. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: used when referring to something that is done as a result of something else
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to do something for you in return/exchange for everything you've done for me.

sense.def: using only a few words
dictionaryExamples: world news in brief
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Now I will tell you in brief what exactly happened to me. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: in someone's opinion
dictionaryExamples: In my parents' eyes, I'll always be a child.

dictionaryExamples: In conclusion, I would like to thank our guest speaker for her fascinating talk.

sense.def: used to say what something is about

sense.def: at a suitable time in the future
dictionaryExamples: The results will be sent to you in due course.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I look forward to hearing from you in due course. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: toward someone
dictionaryExamples: She keeps looking in my direction.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I didn't know why she was talking to me but suddenly she walked in my direction and told me: "I need to know your name". Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: used to explain what something means in a different way
dictionaryExamples: He said he's too busy - in other words he isn't interested.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had had a great time before and had drunk too much alcohol. In other words, they were totally drunk. First Certificate in English; B2; Hungarian

sense.def: An agreement that is in writing is official and is proof of that agreement.
dictionaryExamples: Please confirm your reservation in writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I [am] tell[ing] you in writing that I would like to help you. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: if vegetables or fruit are in season, they are available and ready to eat.
dictionaryExamples: Asparagus is in season at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They celebrate Halloween in October when pumpkins are in season, that's why in the decorations they include them very often; most of the people carve the pumpkins and put some lights inside. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: without telling other people
dictionaryExamples: For years they met in secret.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We met in secret when Mary was busy. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: feeling good/excited/unhappy, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The whole class was in good spirits that day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in high spirits until I got my paper back. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: because of
dictionaryExamples: In view of recent events, we have decided to cancel the meeting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In view of what happened, I would advise you not to try to mislead people like this [again]. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: in order to celebrate or show great respect for someone or something
dictionaryExamples: a banquet in honor of the president
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Besides, if you come these days you will see the local fiesta [at] w[h]ich the local people celebrate special events in honor of our saints. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: If you do something in person, you go somewhere to do it yourself.
dictionaryExamples: You have to collect the document in person.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am looking forward [to] meeting you in person. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: instead of something
dictionaryExamples: Try adding fruit to your cereal in place of sugar.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the advertisement, it [said] that Danny Brook was starring, but in place of him there was a different actor and he was really disap[p]ointing. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: at the start of a situation
dictionaryExamples: Why did you invite her in the first place?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the first place, you were unknown people for me, but now you are my special foreign friends. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: If something is true in practice, this is the real situation.
dictionaryExamples: In practice, the new laws have had little effect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you leave school, you have knowledge but you do not know how to use it in practice. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a place where nobody else can hear you or see what you are doing
dictionaryExamples: The meeting was held in private.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I agree that th[is] should be in private. First Certificate in English; B2; Thai

sense.def: happening or being done now
dictionaryExamples: Repair work is in progress on the south-bound lane of the motorway and will continue until June.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [In] the lower part of your advertisement, it also said there was a theatre restaurant, [but] in fact, it was closed because internal decoration was in progress. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: when compared with something
dictionaryExamples: Salaries are low in relation to the cost of living.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think television has several advantages but also disadvantages in relation to books. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: about or relating to something
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to ask you something in relation to what you said earlier.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In relation to last month's social program, the sightseeing tour of London was d[i]vine, although we didn't get to see the entire city. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: in a particular way, or in many ways
dictionaryExamples: The school has changed in many respects.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: How's your friend Mike? He is in many respects better than [a] computer, isn't he? (Teasing you again, sorry). First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: as an answer to
dictionaryExamples: I'm writing in response to your letter of February 14.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am writing in response to your advertisement, which appeared in the newspaper on November the 23rd, looking for a person to work at weekends in your cafe. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: one after another without a break
dictionaryExamples: He's just won the tournament for the fifth year in a row.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Maradona was the captain of the team, and since he arrived, the team won three championships in a row. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: available in a store or other place
dictionaryExamples: Do you have the book in stock?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Shopping could be annoying if you look at it as a waste of time because you do it every day.  Reorganize your behavior [when] shopping and plan to keep food in stock! First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: in the way described by a rule, law, or wish
dictionaryExamples: Both companies have insisted that they were acting in accordance with the law.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although they do not earn much money in this profession, they try to do their best and judge in accordance with the law which they also have to interpret. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: working together with
dictionaryExamples: The event was organized in association with the Student Council.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This service, which will be [provided] in association with Foster Loft, will be available at the end of 2005. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: in large amounts
dictionaryExamples: to buy in bulk
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I suggest that you buy food in bulk so that you not only save money but also save time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: if something happens
dictionaryExamples: An airbag could save your life in the event of an accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the event of bad weather, it would be wise to plan an alternative to the boat trip, for example a visit of Buckingham Palace or the Houses of Parliament. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: whatever happens
dictionaryExamples: I'm not sure if I'm coming on Friday, but in any event, I'll see you next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In any event, it is incumbent upon all of us to carefully plan our travel matters, so as to take advantage of their several benefits. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the particular way in which something appears or exists
dictionaryExamples: The novel is written in the form of a series of letters.
The medicine comes in the form of a liquid or pills.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For all this, I can only say that I want my money back immediately, or [some] compensation in the form of a real trip to a real country. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: used to say what you really feel or think
dictionaryExamples: In his heart, he knew she was right.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to admit that it was only a [sensi]ble decision, because deep in my heart I knew I want[ed] to learn English. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: because you want something good to happen
dictionaryExamples: She went to Paris in the hope of improving her French.
They wrote to their teacher in the hope that he could help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Dave Bennington, I am writing to you in the hope that you will attend our next event in July. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Korean

sense.def: to help someone and give them an advantage
dictionaryExamples: It may not be in your interest to change jobs so soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is in my interests to meet new people and I find it easy to go and talk to people I do not know. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: If something is done or happens in the light of facts, it is done or happens because of those facts.
dictionaryExamples:
In  light of 
                    the problems we’re having, we have no choice but to close the business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In light of all the things mentioned above, I strongly recommend Alexandra for the job. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: to be lucky or to be able to have or do what you want
dictionaryExamples: "Do you have any tuna sandwiches?" "You're in luck - there's one left."
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was in luck, because my friend, who lived in the same area, had his private car and gave me a lift every day. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: If you do something in moderation, you do not do it too much.
dictionaryExamples: I only drink alcohol in moderation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While shopping can make one feel good and even has its positive impact on the retail economy, I think it should be done in moderation. International English Language Testing System; C1; Tagalog

sense.def: something that you say when you are describing something using as few words as possible
dictionaryExamples: The answer, in a nutshell, is yes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To put it in a nutshell, they all provide good food at reasonable prices. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: approximately
dictionaryExamples: It probably cost somewhere in the region of £900.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am willing [to] pay rent in the region of £1000 to £1200 monthly. International English Language Testing System; C1; Urdu

sense.def: ready to be used if or when you need it
dictionaryExamples: She keeps a little money in reserve.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be an idea to have some activity in reserve if you have to cancel something, such as the boat trip on the Thames. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: very soon
dictionaryExamples: We'll be home in no time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Team work is very important for us and you will make many friends in no time. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: singing or playing the right notes
dictionaryExamples: Try to stay in tune.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The public was singing in tune with Jag, hands were raised and bodies were slowly [sway]ing. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: as a result of something that is part of a series of events
dictionaryExamples: This could result in the loss of certain species of fish and this in turn poses a serious threat to the fishing communities along the river banks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This, in turn, enabled them to find jobs and become financially independent from their husbands. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: one after the other in an agreed order
dictionaryExamples: She spoke to each of the guests in turn.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had two different teachers in the mornings and in the afternoons, in turn. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: without any success
dictionaryExamples: I tried in vain to start a conversation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We looked in vain for the guide through three London parks. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

blocks.phrase: in no way/not in any way

sense.def: not at all
dictionaryExamples: This is in no way your fault.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This magazine will be loved by students as it will help them learn English in the best way and in no way will students find it boring. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: being cared for or dealt with by someone skilled
dictionaryExamples: The project is in safe hands - Jan has lots of experience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He has also been trained as a lifeguard so the residents of your hotel would probably be in safe hands. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: similarly
dictionaryExamples: In the same way, there are many citizens who feel unprotected by the police.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the same way, grandmothers may be shocked when seeing their little children wearing extravagant clothes or really short skirts. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: thinking about something in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: In a sense, he's right.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In a sense this is correct, since you have to leave your natural environment to visit a place where no human being is meant to survive. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: in a few words
dictionaryExamples: In short, we need more staff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In short, ancient Chinese poems, mainly [from the] Jang D[yna]sty, constitute [the] background for Chinese culture and set a touchstone for judgement in our life. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: going to happen soon
dictionaryExamples: You never know what's in store for you.
There's a bit of a shock in store for him when he gets home tonight!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nobody knows what the future will have in store! Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; German

sense.def: expecting something to happen or in preparation for something happening
dictionaryExamples: She's even decorated the spare room in anticipation of your visit.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This has sometimes resulted in the comic phenomenon of people traveling to a distant country, in anticipation of encountering strange and original lifestyles, only to come across situations not very different [from] the one they have left in their own countries. International English Language Testing System; C2; Greek

sense.def: present at an event
dictionaryExamples: They have doctors in attendance at every match.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Professional coach[e]s are in attendance and the members can have proper lessons. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: to feel great respect for and sometimes fear of someone
dictionaryExamples: As children we were rather in awe of our grandfather.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I was the eldest of [the] siblings, they used to respect all my orders and [even] now, they are a bit in awe of me. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: as well as everything else
dictionaryExamples: Caffeine has no good effects on health and is mildly addictive in the bargain.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: More or less few people are, in the bargain, prepared to adapt themselves to the others in order to be accepted. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

blocks.phrase: in the blink of an eye

sense.def: extremely quickly
dictionaryExamples: In the blink of an eye, he was gone.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I got dressed [i]n the blink of an eye and I got down to the kitchen almost rolling down the stairs. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to be in the same unpleasant situation as other people
dictionaryExamples: She complains that she doesn't have enough money, but we're all in the same boat.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unemployment and its consequences is still a major problem. Now we are in the same boat. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: not knowing about something because other people are not telling you
dictionaryExamples: They kept us in the dark about their plans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Peter had always kept her in the dark about the reason for their fight. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: wanted or needed in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: Good teachers are always in demand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many goods are not in demand because each family produces [its] own goods. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: used to say what the real situation is
dictionaryExamples: This means, in effect, that the plan has been scrapped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, if the government increases the amount of money they pay to the unemployed, that in effect means higher taxes for the citizens which will cause strikes and various other problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: used to emphasize the most important idea or quality of something
dictionaryExamples: In essence, its purpose is to contain information.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In essence, homelessness means that you don't have a home and because of this you are living on the streets. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: while having to deal with a difficult situation or problem
dictionaryExamples: They left home in the face of strong opposition from their families.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: No doubt, it was rather difficult to like Enid X. She was hardly likely to arouse sympathy in anybody even in the face of death. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: in a difficult situation that causes you trouble or problems
dictionaryExamples: He’s in a fix and needs our help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She felt happy when I was down in the dumps or in a fix and kept on being jealous of me concerning trivial matters. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: immediately, or very quickly
dictionaryExamples: I'll be back in a flash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He took it and, in a flash, he came up to the surface. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a law, rule, etc. is in force, it exists and is being used.
dictionaryExamples: New regulations limiting fishing on this river are now in force.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Because the measures are only in Patra they are not very powerful because it isn't an official law so that it is always in force. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: being worked on or dealt with now
dictionaryExamples: Don't worry – we have the situation  in hand.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Miss Kenton keeps asking Stevens whether everything is in hand and whether her help is required. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: used to give your opinion about something, often when you are sure you are right
dictionaryExamples: In my humble opinion, that's the wrong decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my humble opinion, there's no such thing as a uniform celebrity, good, bad or otherwise. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: Something that is in its infancy has only just begun to develop.
dictionaryExamples: In the 1950s, space travel was in its infancy.

sense.def: in order to achieve a particular situation or quality
dictionaryExamples: In the interest of safety, passengers are advised to wear their seat belts at all times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, do make sure that the front door is always locked. In the interests of everybody's security, it is essential to remember [this]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: alone, or separately from other people, places, or things
dictionaryExamples: These poems cannot be considered in isolation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, it is my opinion that the problem of parking space cannot be solved in isolation. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: almost certainly
dictionaryExamples: The facilities are wasted on people who in all likelihood will not use them.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In all likelihood, you will have to work during the weekends, even in summer, so I firmly believe that loving your job is very important. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: to be similar to and suitable for something
dictionaryExamples: They were offered a pay increase in line with inflation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The other two courses, at 5%, are still in line with the national average. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: If you do something in memory of a dead person, you do it to show your respect or love for them.
dictionaryExamples: They built a statue in memory of those who died in the fire.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You see, every year our family performs a certain gathering in memory of my brother who was killed in a plane crash in 1991 known as the C130 disaster. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in your imagination or memory
dictionaryExamples: In my mind's eye, I imagined the building painted white, with a beautiful garden around it.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He sees her in his mind's eye, running around barefoot, laughing and squealing, wading in the water and running back out, screaming, trying to get away from the breaking waves. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If something is in miniature, it is a very small copy of something else.
dictionaryExamples: a model of the ship in miniature
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thirdly a co-educational school is a society in miniature and it has many practical advantages. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: If bad things are done in the name of something, they are done in order to help that thing succeed.
dictionaryExamples: Are you willing to work yourself to death in the name of competition?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are things one cannot trifle with: friendship for example should not be sacrificed in the name of success. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: combined into a single thing
dictionaryExamples: It's a vacation and art course all in one.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Internet is like combining a television, a telephone and an airplane all in one. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: partly
dictionaryExamples: He is in part to blame for the accident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Technology is in part to blame. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: when things are in perspective, you think about them in a sensible and  realistic way, and understand how important or unimportant they really are
dictionaryExamples: You must keep things in perspective - the overall situation isn't really that bad.
When you see pictures of their suffering, it puts your own problems in perspective.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think it will enable me to see things more in perspective. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: in the correct position
dictionaryExamples: The chairs are all in place.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I looked neat and clean even after the wildest games in the school yard, with all the ribbons that tied my long hair in place. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: If a rule, system, etc. is in place, it has started to exist.
dictionaryExamples: There are now laws in place to prevent this from happening.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let's take [the] example of Mexico City, where such restrictions have been in place since early 2000. International English Language Testing System; C2; Russian

sense.def: used to mean that something is very likely
dictionaryExamples: She will, in all probability, have left before we arrive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anybody who can fulfill the above conditions will in all probability be successful. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: If something changes in proportion to another thing, it changes to the same degree as that thing.
dictionaryExamples: Your tax payment increases in proportion to your salary.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One aspect of the question is the fact that a sportsman's salary is supposedly not in proportion to the number of hours he work[s]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the person or thing that is being discussed
dictionaryExamples: He sais that he was at a restaurant with his friends on the night in question.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While this is not necessarily false, it should be borne in mind that the events in question are by no means boring or uninteresting. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: thinking back to something that happened  before
dictionaryExamples: In retrospect, I should probably have told her.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To cut a long story short I decided to go, though half-heartedly as I still had doubts about it. In retrospect, it turned out to be an unforget[t]able experience. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in a bad situation where you do the same things all the time, or where it is impossible to make progress
dictionaryExamples: He seems to be stuck in a rut at the moment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Financial security, all the, let me call them, background benefits are important, but if you do not love what you do, soon you will become bitter, stuck in a rut or worse - you will suffer from depression. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to be acceptable in a way that will not upset or anger people
dictionaryExamples: His speech was in good taste.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I therefore t[h]ought that it would be in good taste to write about two of them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: to be unacceptable in a way that will upset or anger people
dictionaryExamples: He told a joke about a plane crash which I thought was in rather poor taste.

sense.def: in a direct and often angry way
dictionaryExamples: I told him to go away in no uncertain terms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Intellectuals are used to saying in no uncertain terms that money represents the bad side of the sport. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to understand what someone wants or needs or to understand a situation and act in a way that is suitable for it
dictionaryExamples: The congress is not in tune with the voters.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am not exactly in tune with all the latest trends but I know which styles give me the most satisfaction. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: in the area near a place
dictionaryExamples: A number of buildings in the vicinity of the fire were damaged.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Just to briefly introduce myself, my name is Prashant Sharma and I live in the vicinity of the college campus. 
 International English Language Testing System; C2; Hindi

sense.def: used to say that someone or something does something to a large degree
dictionaryExamples: They celebrate birthdays in a big way.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tourism helps Greece's national economy - which is not at its best - in a big way. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to be likely to happen
dictionaryExamples: Do you think marriage is in the cards?

sense.def: not in a difficult situation or having problems any more
dictionaryExamples: We had some large debts, but we should be in the clear by next year.
His lawyers say that Wilson is in the clear.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "You're in the clear, you don't have to be afraid any more," it said. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: in a cruel way, without showing any emotion
dictionaryExamples: He shot three policemen in cold blood.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Returning to the story, when I arrived, I went directly to Hillton Avenue where I should have met 005, but when I arrived at the meeting point I found him lying on the floor with two shots in his back; he had been murdered in cold blood. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: If you tell something to someone in confidence, you do not want them to tell anyone else.
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry, she told me that in confidence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His real name isn't Piggy but he told Ralph in confidence that they called him that in school because of his appearance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: working, used, or happening with something or someone else
dictionaryExamples: Our librarians use their knowledge in conjunction with the computer network.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore if the banning of private cars takes place in conjunction with development in the public transport[ation] system in that city, this whole development will [have] more advantages despite some slight difficulties at the start. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tamil

sense.def: because of or for this reason
dictionaryExamples: This course is good in that it provides a very practical training.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays it is widely argued that professional sports are damaging to people's health in that they involve grueling training sessions as an integral part of the occupation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: into an area or space from the outside of it
dictionaryExamples: Could you bring the clothes in for me?
Cut the pastry into a square and turn in the corners.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First I brought in the big cake that my father had [bought]. Key English Test; A2; Farsi

sense.def: at the place where a person usually lives or works
dictionaryExamples: Mr Ellis isn't in this week.
Could you ask him to call me when he gets in?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We go in at 8[:]15. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: having arrived at the place where people can get on or off
dictionaryExamples: What time is Roz's flight due in?

sense.def: given or sent to someone official in order to be read
dictionaryExamples: When does your essay have to be in?
Remember to get your application in by the end of the week.

blocks.phrase: the ins and outs of sth

sense.def: the details of a particular subject
dictionaryExamples: the ins and outs of the legal system
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I knew all the ins and outs of every story but I couldn't stay one single day in bed without reading it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: lack of ability to do something
dictionaryExamples: I'm concerned about our inability to find someone for this job.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: The Arnewood's inability to cater for special diets gives the Lawson House the upper hand, since there are 3 vegetarians coming along. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: something such as a statement or number that is not correct
dictionaryExamples: The report contained many inaccuracies.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Apart from these inaccuracies, the group members have a lot of complaints. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not correct or exact
dictionaryExamples: inaccurate information
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to your inaccurate information, I was late and missed part of the show. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: not good enough or too low in quality
dictionaryExamples: Our equipment is totally inadequate for a job like this.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I found the seats inadequate and my seat belt was broken. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: not enough
dictionaryExamples: inadequate funds
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, the inadequate number of computers could not cover students' needs. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: not suitable
dictionaryExamples: inappropriate behavior/comments

His casual clothes were inappropriate for such a formal
 
 occasion.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Regarding video facilities, most students characterized them as a nice choice generally, but were not satisfied with the equipment, which they found rather poor and inappropriate. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is not suitable
dictionaryExamples: The meeting was inappropriately handled and an argument broke out.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: For instance, the refreshment tent was inappropriately located, making it difficult for the participants to reach it. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: something that encourages you to act in a particular way
dictionaryExamples: People had little incentive to save.
financial/economic incentives
The government should provide incentives for education.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not surprisingly, they value financial rewards over other kinds of incentives. International English Language Testing System; C2; Georgian

sense.def: a unit used for measuring length that is approximately equal to 2.54 centimeters, sometimes shown by the symbol ″
dictionaryExamples: Twelve inches are equal to one foot.
He had a cut an inch long above his left eye.
The snow was six inches deep in some places.
a piece of wood 2″ by 2″
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He was one inch tall with strange clothes. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: an event, usually one that is either unpleasant or unusual
dictionaryExamples: an isolated/separate/serious incident
We drove through pouring rain for over an hour but arrived home without incident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After that incident I never cheated again and I never talked to that teacher again. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def:
used to introduce something additional that is not as
 
 important or to introduce something new
dictionaryExamples: Incidentally, she was a very popular mayor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Incidentally, there is another big Turkish Bath in Ginarah. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Turkish

sense.def: what you usually are like or prefer, or the feeling that makes you want to do something
dictionaryExamples: Tony has a strong inclination toward the arts.
My inclination is to look for another job.
She showed no inclination to leave.
