sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people do not have any opportunity to find out their inclinations and improve their skills as far as art is concerned. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to contain something or someone as a part, or to make something or someone part of something
dictionaryExamples: The bill includes tax and tip.
Tax and tip are included in the bill.

Sheila asked to be included
 among the people going on the tour.
Your responsibilities will include making appointments on my behalf.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: It includes some songs. 
 Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: used to show that a person or thing is part of a larger group, amount or process
dictionaryExamples: Eight people, including two children, were injured during the storm.
It's $24.99, including postage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [At] my party we danced a lot and everybody was there, including Amanda, Bruna, and Paola. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: when you include someone or something, especially in a group, amount, or event
dictionaryExamples: Her self-portrait was chosen for inclusion in the exhibition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In basketball, for instance, changes in the most important competitions, such as the inclusion of foreign players, have given players the opportunity to be succes[s]ful not only in their country but also worldwide. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: money that you earn by working, investing, or producing goods
dictionaryExamples: Average incomes have risen by 4.5% over the past year.
personal/household/family income
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you are a student, you don't have [any] income. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: impossible to imagine
dictionaryExamples: It's not inconceivable that soon most cars will be battery powered.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, it is inconceivable that a young child should be raised almost without his/her parents, surrounded by myriad toys, gadgets and games instead. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not caring about other people's situations or the way they feel
dictionaryExamples: It was inconsiderate of you to keep everyone waiting.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Some of the tenants have been very inconsiderate in discarding their garbage [on] the back stairway and blocking the fire exits. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: something that is causing difficulty and is annoying, or an annoying situation
dictionaryExamples: The manager apologized for the inconvenience.
Having to wait for ten minutes was a minor inconvenience.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sorry for any inconvenience these requirements may cause to you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; French

sense.def: involving or causing difficulty, such as unexpected changes or effort
dictionaryExamples: I'm sorry, I seem to have called at an inconvenient time.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  Please call him and make an alternative [arrangement] if it is inconvenient for you. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to include something as part of another thing
dictionaryExamples: He began to incorporate dance and mime into his plays.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These are just some of the ideas that I feel can be incorporated into your project. International English Language Testing System; C2; Romansch

sense.def: not correct
dictionaryExamples: an incorrect answer
Your figures are incorrect.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Dear Sir or Madam, I am writing to you concerning some incorrect information about Lampton that I have found in the Student Tourist Guidebook. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to get bigger or to make something bigger in amount or size
dictionaryExamples: Sales of laptops  have increased over the last few years.
The cost of the project has increased dramatically/significantly since it began.
Gradually increase the temperature to the boiling point.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is amazing how the violence in Rio increased in these last few years. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: a rise in the amount or size of something
dictionaryExamples: price/tax increases
There were 39, 000 new cases last year - an increase of 7 per cent.
Any increase in production would be helpful.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Since bicycles became so popular, there has been an increase in the number of accidents. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: If something is on the increase, it is happening more often.
dictionaryExamples:
Homelessness is on the increase in many
 cities.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [The] number of motorists is on the increase everywhere in the world. International English Language Testing System; C1; Czech

sense.def: more and more
dictionaryExamples: to be increasingly important/common
Increasingly, there is pressure on the council to reverse its decision.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Among them are the increasingly popular reality shows and all the daily news about gossip and scandal. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: very good, exciting or large
dictionaryExamples: We had an incredible time that summer.
They gave us an incredible amount of food.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The weather here is incredible and we have the most beautiful beaches in the world, in my opinion. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: impossible, or very difficult, to believe
dictionaryExamples: It seems incredible that no one complained.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was incredible but it was true. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: extremely
dictionaryExamples: I think the team played incredibly well.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was incredibly crowded. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: in a way that is difficult to believe
dictionaryExamples: Incredibly, no one was hurt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Incredibly, and against all my expectations, everything started going wrong from the very begin[n]ing. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: to lose money, owe money, or have to pay money because of something that has happened
dictionaryExamples: The company incurred huge losses as a result of its  investments.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: One of the principal problems is that governments all around the world are incurring great costs in order to maintain a national health system. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: impossible to cure
dictionaryExamples: an incurable disease
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the incurable illnesses of the past are no longer a threat, which means that the people live longer and longer than they used to. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: really or certainly, often used to emphasize something
dictionaryExamples: Indeed, it could be the worst environmental disaster in Western Europe this century.
Evidence suggests that errors may indeed be occurring.
We live in strange times indeed.
Many people are very poor indeed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you very much indeed. Skills for Life (Entry 3); B1; Portuguese

sense.def: used when you say more to support or develop what has already been said
dictionaryExamples: For such creatures speed is not important, indeed it is counterproductive.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It would be very difficult to define a country's culture by choosing only one characteristic of that country; indeed, it is a great variety of things such as language, politics, religion, customs, etc. that shape the culture of every country. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Catalan

sense.def: the grammatical name for the words "a" and "an" in English or words in other languages that have a similar use
for a period of time for which no end has been fixed
dictionaryExamples: His visit has been postponed indefinitely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Each one of them tries so painfully to hide away the natural feelings emanating from within. But it is simply impossible to do so indefinitely. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: when someone looks after themselves and does not need money, help or permission from other people
dictionaryExamples: It's important that parents should allow their children some independence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you follow my instructions, you'll achieve  financial independence sooner than you [would] have thought. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: when a country has its own government and is not ruled by another country
dictionaryExamples: Mexico gained its independence from Spain in 1821.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [After] gaining back our independence after [the] First World War[,] some bright urban ideas came across. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not taking help or money from other people
dictionaryExamples: Grandma's very independent and does all her own shopping and cooking.
I've always been financially independent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm an independent person, and I like to be. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: not influenced or controlled in any way by other people, events or things
dictionaryExamples: an independent inquiry/organization
The group is independent of any political party.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although the variety of films you display is good, there is still a group of independent films you always seems to skip. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: An independent country is not governed or ruled by another country.
dictionaryExamples: Belize became fully independent from Britain in 1981.
Tibet, once an independent country, is now part of China.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After 1918, our city again became [the] capital of [an] independent state. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: in a way that is independent
dictionaryExamples: The two scientists both made the same discovery independently, at roughly the same time.
Each part of the organization operates independently of the others.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: What students should understand is the existence of links among apparently different subjects and the impossibility of studying them independently or, [worse], studying one and neglecting the others. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: an alphabetical list, such as one printed at the back of a book showing which page a subject, name, etc. is found on
dictionaryExamples: Try looking up "heart disease" in the index.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The negative point of the book was its lack of an index. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: to say something or give a signal to show what you mean or what you intend to do
dictionaryExamples: Please indicate which free gift you would like to receive.
She indicated to me (that) she didn't want me to say anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please, indicate if you could attend.  I am looking for[w]ard to your reply. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: to show that something exists or is likely to be true
dictionaryExamples: Recent evidence indicates that the skeleton is about 3 million years old.

These statistics might indicate quality
 
 problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In fact, the study also indicates that time spent on watching TV has surged, especially during the last decade. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a sign showing that something exists or is likely to be true
dictionaryExamples:
The jury
 
 gave no indication of their decision as they came back into the courtroom.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: [A]ll three cat[e]gories show an indication of cutbacks compared to last year. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: a sign showing what someone means or what they intend to do
dictionaryExamples: Helen's face gave no indication of what she was thinking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Rumor had it that Peter secretly brought roses early every morning to her doorstep, as an indication of his love for her. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: something that shows what a situation is like
dictionaryExamples: Commodity prices can be a useful indicator of inflation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The right-wing thinkers claim that unemployment is one of the indicators in [the] economy, displaying lack of balance between industrial output and citizens' demands. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: when you do not care about something or have any particular opinions about it
dictionaryExamples: an air of indifference
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand, there were some voices expressing their indifference towards money. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: not caring about or interested in someone or something
dictionaryExamples: They are indifferent to the plight of the unemployed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Being a resident of our area yourself, you may not be entirely indifferent to the plans of the local authorities concerning the construction of a new supermarket. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: not directly caused by or connected with something
dictionaryExamples: Indirect effects of the fighting include disease and food shortages.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At school, children should follow many rules. For example, they should finish their homework [and] respect other students' opinion[s].  From these experience[s], children can experience social life in indirect ways, and can learn how to be good members of society. International English Language Testing System; C1; Korean

sense.def: done or caused in a way that is not obvious
dictionaryExamples: indirect costs
an indirect criticism
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Do people seem to be the direct cause of this damage or do they also play an indirect part in generating environmental catastroph[e]? Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: in a way that is not direct
dictionaryExamples: She still controls the company indirectly, through her son.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Here we make use of rain water, which is indirectly produced by evaporation of sea water by heat produced by [the] sun. International English Language Testing System; C1; Panjabi

sense.def: completely necessary
dictionaryExamples: an indispensable tool/guide
She quickly became indispensable to him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We should not be led to believe that [computers] are the indispensable ingredient to our well-being, [though] neither should we deny their wide-ranging potential. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: obviously and certainly true
dictionaryExamples: an indisputable fact
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Taking all the aforementioned into consideration, I adamantly believe that the contribution of reading to all aspects of our lives is indisputable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: considered separately from the other things in a group
dictionaryExamples: Say the individual letters of each word out loud.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, this place is [a group of] small individual islands and there are[n't] many things that you can do [in] the capital city as it's so small and crowded. Preliminary English Test; B1; Others

sense.def: given to or relating to one particular person or thing
dictionaryExamples: We deal with each case on an individual basis.
We all have an individual password.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The first lesson started with an individual presentation. Preliminary English Test; B1; Swedish

sense.def: a person, especially when considered separately and not as part of a group
dictionaryExamples: We try to treat our students as individuals.
Every individual has rights which must never be taken away.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can work as part of a team but also as an individual. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: a person with a particular characteristic
dictionaryExamples: a ruthless individual
These are all hard-working individuals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I can understand that he is nervous and that [he] has turned into a selfish individual who only cares about himself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the quality of being different from others
dictionaryExamples: The houses had no character and no individuality.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As an intellectual, he refuses to annihilate his individuality and degenerate into savagery. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: separately rather than with others
dictionaryExamples: I spoke to them all individually.
The candies are individually wrapped.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This has the additional advantage that students can work individually on what seems to be most necessary for them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: happening, used or situated inside a building
dictionaryExamples: indoor sports/activities
an indoor swimming pool
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We played a lot of indoor games at the party. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: into or inside a building
dictionaryExamples: Come indoors, it's cold outside.
Spring bulbs can be grown indoors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I love being indoors, eating or watching TV. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to let yourself do or have something that you enjoy but which may be bad for you
dictionaryExamples:
When I get my first paycheck I’m going to indulge in a
 shopping spree.
Go on, indulge yourself! Have another chocolate.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Eating disorders of various kinds are certainly not unknown to our culture, yet we seem to be less concerned about what we shouldn't do than what we tend to indulge ourselves in. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Hungarian

sense.def: to let someone do or have what they want
dictionaryExamples: She indulged the kids and let them stay up late.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In an attempt to give them instant gratification, their parents do their utmost to fulfill their wishes and as a consequence of this, children become utterly indulged. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: connected with industry, or having a lot of industry and factories, etc.
dictionaryExamples: industrial expansion
an industrial landscape
He has an industrial background.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am sure that both ideas will improve the look of our industrial town. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: the process of developing industries in a country
dictionaryExamples: Japan's rapid industrialization
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With industrialization and economic development, Hong Kong people's standards of living have also improve[d] dramatically. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: Industrialized countries have a lot of industry.
dictionaryExamples: the industrialized nations
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The role of women has changed during the past 100 years but there are still a lot of changes needed not only in developing countries but also in industrialized countries like Germany. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: Industrious people work hard.
dictionaryExamples: He is good at his work and very industrious.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The society wouldn't be as advanced as it is unless we had well educated, efficient and industrious workers. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: the people and activities involved in one type of business
dictionaryExamples: the gas/electricity industry
the tourist industry
manufacturing industries
The computer industry has been booming.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know, I would like to work in [the] tourism industry, so I thought this course could be good to improve my English. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: the production of goods in factories
dictionaryExamples: trade and industry
industry and commerce
The city needs to attract more industry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If you are interested in local industry, there is the Prefectural Local Industry museum. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: not suitable for eating
dictionaryExamples: The meat was inedible.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fruit was rotten, the sandwich inedible. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: Inefficient people or things waste time, money or effort, and do not achieve as much as they should.
dictionaryExamples: an inefficient heating system
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The room-service was inefficient and the rooms were small and uncomfortable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when some groups in a society have more advantages than others
dictionaryExamples: social/racial inequality
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She was surrounded by poverty and inequality and grew more and more dissatisfied with the Government's policies, whether internal or foreign. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: certain to happen and unable to be avoided or prevented
dictionaryExamples: The accident was the inevitable consequence/result/outcome of carelessness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Strikes always cause some problems but sometimes they are inevitable. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: in a way that cannot be avoided
dictionaryExamples: Their arguments inevitably end in tears.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Should you, my humble reader, happen to reach fame and fortune, try never to forget that appearing always as an ordinary human being would inevitably grant you more empathy from the people surro[u]nding you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: cheap but of good quality
dictionaryExamples: inexpensive children's clothes
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It has far more advantages than the countryside, starting with the excellent accommodation, which is inexpensive and easy to find. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: without much experience or knowledge of something
dictionaryExamples: Abigail Kennedy was young and inexperienced.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The advertisement said that Danny Brook was one of the starring actors but he was replaced by another extremely disappointing and inexperienced actor. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: so strange or unusual that you cannot understand or explain it
dictionaryExamples: To me his behavior was totally inexplicable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although for inexplicable reasons she can be really stubborn sometimes, I admire her courage to admit her mistakes and apologize. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when you are a baby
dictionaryExamples: Their fourth child died in infancy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When the Romans conquered the world, [the] child death rate was much higher than now and those who survived infancy hardly ever got beyond forty years of age. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: Something that is in its infancy has only just begun to develop.
dictionaryExamples: In the 1950s, space travel was in its infancy.

sense.def: a baby or very young child
dictionaryExamples: Mothers and infants were allowed to board the plane first.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The cells are extremely active while we are infants, but as we grow older, their efficiency weakens. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to give someone a disease
dictionaryExamples: Thousands of people were infected with the virus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Furthermore, most times the hotels expel their waste to the sea and they pollute the water.  Consequently, a lot of people have been infected by different kinds of ailments. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: If a computer virus infects a computer, it harms it
dictionaryExamples: My computer was infected by a virus.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With CLEAN-MAIL, you can protect your computers from getting infected with viruses effectively: virus-mails are deleted before they even arrive at your mailbox.  Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: If a place, wound, or substance is infected, it contains bacteria or other things that can cause disease.
dictionaryExamples: The wound became infected.
an infected toe
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Let's try to think to that poor people they caught it in a hospital because they need blood and doctors gave them infected blood without knowing it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: a disease in a part of your body that is caused by bacteria or a virus
dictionaryExamples: a serious infection
a throat infection
Bandage the wound to reduce the risk of infection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He told me that she was suffer[ing] from [a] kidney infection. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: An infectious disease can be passed from one person to another.
dictionaryExamples: Hepatitis is an infectious disease.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, epidemic[s] of major infectious diseases like cholera or meningitis carry the risk of transferring the focus of infection to any part of the world. International English Language Testing System; C2; Arabic

sense.def: Infectious laughter or feelings quickly spread from one person to another.
dictionaryExamples: infectious enthusiasm
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have found that feelings and emotions are infectious and people tend to be happier with people who are fun-loving and take life less seriously. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to guess that something is true because of the information that you have
dictionaryExamples: I inferred from the number of cups that he was expecting visitors.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the above, it can be inferred that the major causes of land degradation var[y] according to regions. International English Language Testing System; C2; Ibo/Igbo

sense.def: not good, or not as good as someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: I've never felt inferior to anyone.
They're selling inferior products at inflated prices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young girls often feel inferior to boys in the same class. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: someone who is considered to be less important than other people
dictionaryExamples: She considered me her inferior.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Broadly speaking, he appears to be an inferior, a non-human, in the opinion of the other boys. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: when someone feels they are not as good as other people or when something is not as good as another thing
dictionaryExamples: With these talented sisters, I always had a feeling of inferiority.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Critics suggest that these policies have not benefited poor black Americans, that they have impeded the development of social problems and that they have inhibited black Americans and other discriminated groups through a deep sense of inferiority. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: extremely large or great
dictionaryExamples: an infinite variety/number of options
She took infinite care with the painting.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the hands of an expert, a computer can be used for an infinite number of things. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: very or very much
dictionaryExamples: Travel is infinitely more comfortable now than it used to be.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To sum up, I would like to say that instead of engaging in relentless debates about the problem it would be infinitely preferable to take action as soon as possible. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: the basic form of a verb that usually follows "to"
dictionaryExamples: In the sentences "I had to go" and "I must go," "go" is an infinitive.
"Go" is the infinitive form.

sense.def: the rate at which prices increase, or a continuing increase in prices
dictionaryExamples: high/low inflation
the rate of inflation
3% inflation
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In this country of high inflation we could save some money. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the power to affect how someone thinks or behaves, or how something develops
dictionaryExamples: The drug companies can have a lot of influence on doctors.
At the time she was under the influence of her father.
Picasso had a big influence on art in the twentieth century.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Today's computers have a massive influence on the whole [of]  society. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: If someone or something is a bad/good influence on someone, they have a bad/good effect on them.
dictionaryExamples: Television can be a bad influence on children.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people say that cell phones are a bad influence on the younger generation. First Certificate in English; B2; Swiss German

sense.def: to affect or change how someone or something develops, behaves or thinks
dictionaryExamples: Were you influenced by anybody at the beginning of your career?
What influenced you to choose a career in nursing?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Our life has been influenced by modern technology. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: having a lot of influence
dictionaryExamples: an influential figure in modern jazz
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Although not being directly involved in global politics anymore, he is still a very powerful and influential person. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: the arrival of a lot of people or things at the same time
dictionaryExamples: The town’s economy depends on the summer influx of tourists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Countries are known mainly for their history, that is why there is an influx of tourists in places with historical interest. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: to tell someone about something
dictionaryExamples: If he calls me again, I shall inform the police.
I informed my boss that I was going to be away next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This letter is to inform you that I will not be able to attend tomorrow's class due to medical issues. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to give someone information about something
dictionaryExamples: Patients should be  informed about the risks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, once a month I read gossip magazines and every day I read newspapers to be informed. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: not formal or official
dictionaryExamples: The two groups agreed to hold an informal meeting.
He's the ideal sort of teacher - direct, friendly and informal.
"Hi" is an informal way of greeting people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dress-code is informal but neat and there'll be plenty of drinks and snacks. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: in an informal way
dictionaryExamples: It's an outdoor party, so dress informally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We dress casually and very informally and you often see body piercings and tat[t]oos being displayed around the place. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: facts about a situation, person, event, etc.
dictionaryExamples: to find out/get information
Do you have any information about/on train times?
I read an interesting bit/piece of information in the newspaper.
For further information, please contact your local library.
We have reliable information that a strike is planned next month.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For other information call me on 753784 Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: containing a lot of useful facts
dictionaryExamples: a very informative lecture
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There were presentations from many different industries, some of them very informative and entertaining. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swiss German

sense.def: the basic systems and services, such as transport and power supplies, that a country or organization uses in order to work effectively
dictionaryExamples: The war has badly damaged the country's infrastructure.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is very easy to build homes but at the same time forgetting to upgrade the infrastructure and facilities. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Dutch

sense.def: a food that is used with other foods in the preparation of a particular dish
dictionaryExamples: The list of ingredients included 1/2 cup of almonds.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The  chef had used good, fresh ingredients. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: one of the parts of something successful
dictionaryExamples: Trust is an essential ingredient in a successful marriage.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my opinion it is clear that with these "ingredients" you can make an  interesting video about [daily] life at our school. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: to live in a place
dictionaryExamples: an area inhabited by artists and writers
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Uncountable species inhabit this vast territory of i[m]penetrable, deep forest. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a person or animal that lives in a particular place
dictionaryExamples: a city of 5 million inhabitants
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the town has about 2000 inhabitants in winter. First Certificate in English; B2; Czech

sense.def: existing as a natural and basic part of something
dictionaryExamples: The desire for freedom is inherent in all people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, it is important to bear in mind the inherent pressures that come with fortune and fame. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to receive money or possessions from someone after that person has died
dictionaryExamples: Who will inherit the house when he dies?
All her children will inherit equally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wouldn't mind if it was just a scratch to any other [piece of] furniture, but I couldn't contain myself when my mother burst into tears looking at a broken leg of an antique chair inherited from my grandfather. International English Language Testing System; C2; Tagalog

sense.def: to have the same physical or mental characteristics as one of your parents or grandparents
dictionaryExamples: Miranda has inherited her father's red hair.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her grandparents were from Sweden, and she had inherited blond hair and blue eyes from them. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: money or possessions that becone yours after someone dies
dictionaryExamples: Nick has sold off much of his inheritance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He went to Oxford and by the time he was forty he had set up a good textile factory in London with his inheritance. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: a feeling of embarrassment or worry that prevents you from saying or doing what you want
dictionaryExamples: The whole point about dancing is to lose all your inhibitions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Secondly, parents are the closest and most easily accessible wealth of knowledge. Children lose their inhibitions and freely ask their curious questions. International English Language Testing System; C2; Nepali

sense.def: extremely cruel
dictionaryExamples: the inhuman treatment of prisoners
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Not very long ago, when some of us thought it wasn't possible anymore, the same terrible inhuman mistakes as in the past [were happening]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Turkish

sense.def: the first letter of a name, especially when used to represent a name
dictionaryExamples: He wrote his initials, P.M.R., at the bottom of the page.
Paul M. Reynolds refused to say what the initial "M" stood for.
They carved their initials into a tree.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was black and my initials [were] inside it. Preliminary English Test; B1; Korean

sense.def: first, or happening at the beginning
dictionaryExamples: My initial reaction was one of anger.
Initial reports say that seven people have died, though this has not yet been confirmed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: All this may seem trivial [and] unimportant to an ordinary man addicted to his TV-set, forgetting the initial impulse that made him cho[o]se this way [of life]. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: at the beginning
dictionaryExamples: Initially, most people approved of the new plan.
The damage was far more serious than initially believed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He initially disagreed with his wife but after much persuasion, he finally gave in. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to make something begin
dictionaryExamples: The reforms were initiated by Gorbachev.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I hope the college will initiate interesting new courses, regardless of financia[l] issues, to promote a good image. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: a plan or activity that is done to solve a problem or improve a situation
dictionaryExamples: a new government initiative to reduce crime
The peace initiative was welcomed by both sides.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Any government as well as grass root initiative will have an effect on pollution problems, but firstly, we need to change our society's overall mentality. International English Language Testing System; C1; Danish

sense.def: the ability to make decisions and do things without needing to be told what to do
dictionaryExamples: We need someone who can work on their own initiative.
I shouldn't always have to tell you what to do - use your initiative.
She showed a lot of initiative.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is difficult to judge whether you [show] more initiative than the others or not. International English Language Testing System; C1; Chinese

sense.def: to be the first person to do something that solves a problem or improves a situation
dictionaryExamples: Jackson had taken the initiative and prepared a report.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I took the initiative to contact Sue Wilton, who is the manager of the restaurant "El Plato". Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when someone puts a drug into your body using a needle
dictionaryExamples: an injection of insulin
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This visit was only to be the beginning of it all, as numerous trips to the hospital, fertility clinics, pills and injections soon became a part of their lives together. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: when a large amount of money is provided for a plan, service, organization, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The university has welcomed the $5 million cash injection.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are few areas such as the information technology, library resources and overseas visits, that need this financial injection. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to hurt a person, animal or part of your  body
dictionaryExamples: A bomb exploded at the embassy, injuring several people.
She fell and injured her shoulder.
He was badly/seriously injured in the crash.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nobody from my family was injured, so that was one good [piece] of news. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: hurt or physically harmed
dictionaryExamples: She was told to stay in bed to rest her injured back.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Zoos can take care of injured animals and help them. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: damage to someone's body in  an accident or an attack
dictionaryExamples: a head/back/knee injury
a serious/slight injury
Injuries to the spine are common among these workers.
They were lucky to escape (without) injury.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I understood that nobody was serious[ly] hurt but we all had some injuries. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to make someone's bad situation worse by doing something else to upset them
dictionaryExamples: To add insult to injury, we had to pay for the damage!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To add insult to injury, such an approach often turns out to be counterproductive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a situation or action in which people are treated unfairly
dictionaryExamples: the fight against racial injustice
the injustices of the legal system
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Adults enjoy the stories too, because it somehow reflects the society that we live in, and how justice is always [on] the stronger side than injustice. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: a colored liquid that you use for writing, printing, or drawing
dictionaryExamples: a bottle of ink
blue/black/red ink
Please write in ink, not in pencil.
The book is printed in three different colored inks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Her father had shown her once how to write with an invisible ink. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: An innate quality or ability is one that you were born with, not one you have learned.
dictionaryExamples: He has an innate desire to win.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His innate ability to act as a motivator for other people has helped him obtain excellent leadership skills. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: on the inside or near the middle of something
dictionaryExamples: Leading off the main hall is a series of small inner rooms.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Even in the inner city,  streets are dark and don't give the feeling of safety after sunset. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: Inner feelings or thoughts are ones that you do not show or tell other people.
dictionaryExamples: Sarah always seemed to have a deep sense of inner peace.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every now and then everybody feels an inner call for changes, and one of [those] changes might be a journey somewhere in the world. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: when someone is not guilty of a crime
dictionaryExamples: She pleaded her innocence, but no one believed her.
She fought to prove her son's innocence.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They were released after seven years in jail and were determined to prove their innocence and find the real murderer. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: when someone does not have much experience of life and does not know about the bad things that happen
dictionaryExamples: the innocence of childhood
She has a childlike innocence which I find very appealing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From the day we're born, our awareness of the world and its people increases. With it comes knowledge and capability but also the loss of innocence. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: not guilty of committing a crime
dictionaryExamples: He firmly believes that she is innocent of the crime.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The plan works: the jury thinks that the wife is a notorious liar and her husband is found innocent. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: not having much experience of life and not knowing about the bad things that can happen
dictionaryExamples: an innocent young woman
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She is so innocent and doesn't understand anything which is happening around [her]. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: used to emphasize that someone who was hurt had done nothing wrong
dictionaryExamples: Several innocent civilians were killed in the bombing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While Jem was ste[a]ling horses, his brother was a murderer of innocent people. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not intended to harm or upset anyone
dictionaryExamples: It was an innocent mistake.
It was an innocent comment/remark, I didn't mean to hurt his feelings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the spur of the moment, I advised him to try it and that's what turned a[n] innocent episode into a nigh[t]mare. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: in an innocent way
dictionaryExamples: "Have I done something wrong?" she asked innocently.
He said he had obtained the television innocently, not knowing it had been stolen.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Denny had innocently [turned on] the light to see if there was anything of interest in the other room. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a new idea or method that is being tried for the first time, or the use of such ideas or methods
dictionaryExamples: the latest innovations in education
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There was a barrage of creativity and innovation rarely seen in human history. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: using new methods or ideas
dictionaryExamples:
The new owners introduced
 
 a number of innovative solutions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Problems like this will probably app[ea]r again and again but we have to beli[e]ve that they can be solved in an innovative way. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: very many, or too many to count
dictionaryExamples: innumerable problems
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Modern aviation also created innumerable benefits for the people in general. International English Language Testing System; C2; Urdu

sense.def: ideas, money, effort, etc. that you put into a process or acitivity in order to help it succeed
dictionaryExamples: Input from students is used to develop new and exciting courses.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I could go on but my intention was to give you some input to stimulate your brain! First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: information that is put into a computer or the act of putting information into a computer
dictionaryExamples: Data input is carried out by a team based overseas.

sense.def: to ask for information
dictionaryExamples: Should I inquire about the price of tickets?
She called to inquire whether her car would be ready by 5.
"Where are we going?" he inquired.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: "Say Mary, when did the war beg[i]n?" inquired the old lady. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a question that you ask when you want more information
dictionaryExamples: I've made some inquiries about the cost of a round-the-world ticket.
Inquiry into the matter is pointless - no one will tell you anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From what I understand from your inquiry you are looking for a babysitter to take care of three children aged 8, 6 and 3 on Saturday evenings and [o]ccasionally on Sunday afternoons. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: an official process to discover the facts about something bad that has happened
dictionaryExamples: a judicial inquiry
Citizens have demanded a full inquiry into the government's handling of the epidemic.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am very much surprised that such [problems] had not been foreseen by the public inquiry. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: the process of asking questions in order to get information
dictionaryExamples: Inquiry into the matter is pointless - no one will tell you anything.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Upon inquiry, it became clear it was in Tim's possession, more precisely in his diary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: very silly or stupid
dictionaryExamples: an insane decision
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was an insane idea to accom[m]odate me so far away from the school (approximately four miles). Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: seriously mentally ill
dictionaryExamples: a hospital for the criminally insane
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seemed as if she had become insane but it was only a way of surviving an impossible situation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: a small creature with six legs, for example a bee or a fly
dictionaryExamples: Ants, beetles, butterflies and flies are all insects.
I've got some sort of insect bite on my leg.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example:  [T]here are a lot of butterflies in the park, [and] they are beautiful insects.  Key English Test; A2; German

sense.def: having no confidence in yourself and what you can do
dictionaryExamples: a shy, insecure teenager
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People felt insecure and nervous, their morale went down. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: not safe or protected
dictionaryExamples: Many of our staff are worried because their jobs are insecure.

sense.def: the state of not being confident or not feeling safe
dictionaryExamples: We have to live with the insecurity of not knowing if we'll still have a job next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Many of us have experienced moments of insecurity when everything seems so big and new that you wonder if you can deal with all the pressure or whether you will eventually manage to adapt to the situation at hand. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Bulgarian

sense.def: not noticing or not caring about other people's feelings
dictionaryExamples: an insensitive remark
He was completely insensitive to Maria's feelings.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This way of thinking is very important because a person who spends a lot of time alone can become self-cent[e]red and insensitive to others. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: Two things that are inseparable are so closely connected that you cannot consider them separately.
dictionaryExamples: Rossetti's work was inseparable from his life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The memory and the experience you have [of] the object create a special bond between you and the object, and the bond makes you inseparable from the object because you are inseparable from the memory. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: People who are inseparable are always together because they are such good friends.
dictionaryExamples: The two girls got on very well and soon became inseparable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were inseparable pals playing th[at] favorite game of ours day and night. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Korean

sense.def: to put something into something else
dictionaryExamples: Insert the coin in the slot.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You just insert the CD-ROM; [the] rest will [happen] automatically. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: to add something to the middle of a document or piece of writing
dictionaryExamples: He inserted a new paragraph.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the future it will be possible to buy paintings via the internet. The prices will be inserted under each painting. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Swedish

sense.def: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionaryExamples: There were some keys inside the box.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I kept it inside the jewel box. Key English Test; A2; Tamil

sense.def: in or into a room, building, container, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I'm freezing, let's go back inside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We can stay inside and play with the computer. Key English Test; A2; Norwegian

sense.def: If you have a feeling inside, you have a feeling although you might not show it to other people.
dictionaryExamples: She couldn't cope with the grief she felt inside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: They had to go to the vet more often but it wasn't hard for them because of the love that they felt inside. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: in or on the part of something under its surface
dictionaryExamples: He put the documents carefully in his inside pocket.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: At first Chris didn't seem to recognize him, but as soon as he did, his hand reached [into] his inside pocket. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: information that is only known by people who are part of an organization, group, etc.
dictionaryExamples: I needed someone with inside knowledge to back up my story.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm pretty sure that getting in touch with the customs and lifestyle of another country will open a completely new horizon to the students and they'll be enchanted by the 'inside knowledge' they will be able to gain. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the inner part, space or side of something
dictionaryExamples: Did you clean the inside of the car?
The hotel looked shabby from the street, but it was fine on the inside.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Anyway, after the show I felt hungry so I went to the restaurant but it was closed because they were having the inside altered. First Certificate in English; B2; [no L1 data]

sense.def: If a piece of clothing is inside out, the part that is usually outside is  on the inside.
dictionaryExamples: She had her sweater on inside out.

sense.def: to know everything about something
dictionaryExamples: He knows the system inside out.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The participants got to know Britain inside out and they are happy with the knowledge they gained. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Chinese

sense.def: the ability to understand what something is really like, or an example of this
dictionaryExamples: The book gives a fascinating insight into the world of art.
This new research provides many insights into customer behavior.
Children sometimes show remarkable insight when it comes to adult problems.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Special courses were offered, which provided deep insights in[to] fascinating topics - they were great fun. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: not important or large enough to consider or worry about
dictionaryExamples: insignificant differences
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Second, the "sudden downpour of rain" you reported and which "ruined" the show was actually a short and insignificant one that only lasted a few minutes. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: to demand that something must be done or that you must have a particular thing
dictionaryExamples: He insists we leave at 8:30.
She insisted on seeing her lawyer.
Please go first - I insist!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But if they insist, you should listen to them because our parents love us and they want the best for us. Preliminary English Test; B1; Turkish

sense.def: to say firmly that something is true
dictionaryExamples: Greg still insists (that) he did nothing wrong.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mrs. McGillicuddy saw a woman being strangled [o]n a train and, in spite of everybody seem[ing] not to believe her, she insisted that she was right and, with her friend's help, proved it. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to keep doing something, even if it annoys other people or people think it is not good for you
dictionaryExamples: She insists on cooking all her own meals.
Frank insisted on doing all the work himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Young people often insist on doing everything on their own and consider advice almost an attack on their personal opinion.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: to the degree that
dictionaryExamples: The story is based insofar as possible on notes made by Scott himself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Consequently the cited statement is definitely true but understates its point insofar as it neglects any time horizon. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when you find it difficult to sleep
dictionaryExamples: Many people suffer from insomnia.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If we take the example of the politicians, we will find that those who are honest are the ones who suffer from insomnia (caused by threats and worries) while the most corrupt ones are safe asleep. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to look at something or someone carefully in order to discover information, especially about their quality or condition
dictionaryExamples: After the crash, both drivers got out and inspected their cars for damage.
She held the bank note up to the light and inspected it carefully.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I invite you to inspect our facilities [so] that you can persuade yourself about the lack of equipment. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: an official look to check that something is correct, legal, or in good condition
dictionaryExamples: Fire officers carried out an inspection of the building.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: According to the contract signed with your company on September 25th 2008, an inspection of the goods was done at the time of the packing. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: when you look at something carefully
dictionaryExamples: On closer inspection, the painting was discovered to be a fake.

sense.def: someone whose job is to check that things are being done correctly
dictionaryExamples: a health/safety inspector
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My grandfather was a ticket inspector and he was always [telling] incredible stories about the old times when train was the fastest way of traveling. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: a police officer of high rank
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As you know I am a police inspector. First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: someone or something that gives you ideas for doing something
dictionaryExamples: The golden autumn light provided the inspiration for the painting.
He went to church, perhaps seeking divine inspiration.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Working with children makes me happy and gives me inspiration. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: to be so good that someone else admires you and is encouraged by your behavior
dictionaryExamples: The way she has dealt with her illness is an inspiration to us all.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She will always be an inspiration to me for her great strength, knowledge and courage. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: a sudden good idea about what you should do
dictionaryExamples: I've had an inspiration about Andy's birthday present.

sense.def: to make someone feel that they want to do something and can do it
dictionaryExamples: A drama teacher at school had  inspired Sam to become an actor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This has inspired me to finally write to you and ask if there is a possibility for me to join the painting course this spring. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: to make someone have a particular feeling or reaction
dictionaryExamples: He inspires great loyalty in his staff.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In today's world where everybody is selfish, it is hard to find a person to admire, a [role] model to be inspired by. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: to give someone an idea for a book, play, painting, etc.
dictionaryExamples: This television drama was inspired by a true story.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of her books are inspired by her life in Bulgaria and the adventures she [had] herself. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: to put a computer program onto a computer so that the computer can use it
dictionaryExamples: Andrew, can you help me install this software?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We have learned how to install components like a Soundboard or a CD-Rom drive. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: to put a piece of equipment somewhere and make it ready for use
dictionaryExamples: The plumber is coming tomorrow to install the new washing machine.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On my third day I helped them to install the sound system. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the process of putting new equipment into position
dictionaryExamples: Do you have to pay extra for installation?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last but not least, students asked for the installation of a beverage machine - that would be really convenient for them. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: the process of putting a computer program onto a computer
dictionaryExamples: the installation of new software
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Personally, I beli[e]ve that the installation of the Japanese Word version could considerably improve the efficiency of my work. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: happening immediately, without any delay
dictionaryExamples: This type of account offers you instant access to your money.
Contrary to expectations, the movie was an instant success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Therefore, the reception should be functional for students, that is, the students should get [an] instant answer when they have a question. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: immediately
dictionaryExamples: Both drivers were killed instantly.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To talk to a friend from another city or country instantly online is really nice and exciting. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: in place of someone or something else
dictionaryExamples: There's no coffee - would you like a cup of tea instead?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I don't want to use the dark blue paint. I am going to use the sky-blue paint instead. Key English Test; A2; Malay

sense.def: in place of
dictionaryExamples: You can go instead of me, if you want.
We should book the flights now instead of waiting until next week.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I had to admit that I would prefer to go with my friends and I decided to go with them instead of being with my parents. Preliminary English Test; B1; Vietnamese

sense.def: the way someone naturally reacts or behaves, without having to think or learn about it
dictionaryExamples: a mother's instinct to protect her children
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unfortunately, there is a tendency for parental protection, which is a natural instinct of any parent regarding the safety of one's child. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: an organization where people do a particular kind of scientific, educational or social work, or the buildings which it uses
dictionaryExamples: the Massachusetts Institute of Technology
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With this jump she would raise money for a cancer institute in London. First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: a large and important organization, such as a university or bank
dictionaryExamples: a medical/educational/financial institution
Oxford and Cambridge universities are internationally respected institutions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Firstly, it's important to gain information about the institution where we want to work. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: a building where people are sent so they can be looked after, for example a prison or a hospital
dictionaryExamples: a young offenders' institution
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was working for a social institution that looks after poor children. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: a custom that has existed for a long time
dictionaryExamples: the institution of marriage
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nowadays, the institution of mar[r]iage seems to be coming back into fashion, and many youngsters who regrd themselves as mature experience wedlock at an increasingly early age. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Ewe

sense.def: to officially tell someone to do something
dictionaryExamples: Employees are instructed not to use the telephones for personal calls.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were instructed to pack all our belongings in the boxes that w[ere] provided by your company as well as bubble wrap all furniture as per the instructions. International English Language Testing System; C1; Afrikaans

sense.def: to teach someone about something
dictionaryExamples: She is there to instruct people in the safe use of the gym equipment.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He instructed her in Chinese boxing, pretending that she was a male, and she spent five years of her childhood performing hard exercises, while Mui was playing with other girls. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: someone who teaches a particular sport or activity
dictionaryExamples: a driving instructor
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are professional instructors work[ing] in this club. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: an object that is used for playing music, such as a piano, guitar or drum
dictionaryExamples: They all brought musical instruments with them.
Which instrument do you play?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I play two instruments, so I can help you with the concert, playing guitar or keyboard. Key English Test; A2; Portuguese

sense.def: a tool that is used for doing something
dictionaryExamples: scientific instruments
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can also see Roman medical instruments and tools, for example a pioneer axe and different knives. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: someone or something that is used for achieving something
dictionaryExamples: The Internet is a very powerful instrument of communication.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This mec[h]anical dog, harmless when not powered, is an instrument of repression and terror. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: not enough
dictionaryExamples: insufficient information
Her income is insufficient to support a family.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In contrast to your brochure, we did not have any special [entertainment] at the hotel and the dinner was insufficient in terms of not only its quality but also the quantity. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: a rude and offensive remark or action
dictionaryExamples: They were shouting insults at each other.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Joko's mother would hurl insults at the poor old man, calling him sick and [hoping] that he'd die soon. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to make someone's bad situation worse by doing something else to upset them
dictionaryExamples: To add insult to injury, we had to pay for the damage!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To add insult to injury, such an approach often turns out to be counterproductive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to say or do something to someone that is rude and offensive
dictionaryExamples: How dare you insult me in front of my friends!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After all, [in] insulting the performers you insult their fans... First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: an agreement in which you pay a company money and they pay your costs if you have an accident, injury, etc.
dictionaryExamples: life/health/car/travel insurance
I'll need to take out extra car insurance for another driver.
The insurance doesn't cover you for household items.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lastly, could you please tell me what kind of clothes I should prepare and [whether] I have to buy insurance myself? First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: to make something certain to happen
dictionaryExamples: Please insure that your name is at the top of your examination paper.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So in my opinion we can accept keeping animals in zoos but only if we insure them good li[ving] conditions and we do not want to gain profits above all. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: not damaged or destroyed
dictionaryExamples: Many of the old buildings are still intact.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am fortunate that my grandmother kept it intact in her attic until I discovered it two years ago. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: necessary and important as part of something
dictionaryExamples: The Internet has become an integral part of modern life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Over the last few years, computers have become an integral part of our lives. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Polish

sense.def: to become part of a group or society, or to help someone do this
dictionaryExamples: After a few weeks of training he was fully integrated into the team.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am [a] determined, spont[ane]ous person and I have the ability to integrate well. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: when things or people are mixed, joined or combined
dictionaryExamples: cultural integration
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This may be explained by the increasing number of exchanges in the European Union, and the stronger economic integration of European Countries. International English Language Testing System; C1; French

sense.def: honesty and the ability to do or know what is morally right
dictionaryExamples: a woman of great integrity
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This growing shopping mania is also said to create an increasingly materialistic society, hence, our children grow up forgetting the basic values of life - simplicity, integrity, humility and plain hard work. International English Language Testing System; C2; Chinese

sense.def: the ability to learn and understand something, and to form ideas, judgments, and opinions about what you have learned
dictionaryExamples: His energy and intellect are respected by many people.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When I am alone, or in "qualified" company, I may listen to music of a sort that appeals to my intellect as much as to my emotions. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: relating to your ability to think and to understand things, especially complicated ideas
dictionaryExamples: intellectual and physical development
I like detective stories and romances - nothing too intellectual.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, I don't think your programme needs any improvement: in my opinion, your selection of films is already very satisfying because it includes both spectacular Hollywood movies and intellectual films. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: interested in learning and in thinking about complicated ideas
dictionaryExamples: She's very intellectual.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He made a good impression on her from the beginning, dressed in a dark blue evening suit, with a patterned bow tie, glimmering leather shoes and flashing spectacles that made him look very intellectual. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who enjoys studying and thinking about complicated ideas
dictionaryExamples: She was  a real intellectual.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As an intellectual and thinker (the glasses Piggy wears stand for these attributes), he is admired by Ralph, the chief. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: in a way that relates to your ability to think and to understand things
dictionaryExamples: She's hoping to find a job that is more demanding intellectually.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Some people complain that they do not have enough time to develop intellectually when they are in their 20s or 30s because they have to take care of their small children. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the ability to learn, understand and think about things
dictionaryExamples: an intelligence test
a child of high/average/low intelligence
It's the intelligence of her writing that impresses me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dominant [species] among animals are pigs with their superior intelligence. First Certificate in English; B2; Slovene

sense.def: showing intelligence, or able to learn and understand things easily
dictionaryExamples: a highly intelligent young man
an intelligent remark
Helen had a few intelligent things to say on the subject.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I've met my English teacher - she's very friendly and, I think, very intelligent. Preliminary English Test; B1; Indonesian

sense.def: to have as a plan or purpose
dictionaryExamples: We intend to go to Australia next year.

I don't think she intended me to hear the remark.
It was intended as a compliment, honestly!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I intend to invite many friends who were in [the] same university, but nobody knows this news, so I want to surprise them. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: to be made, designed, or provided for a particular person or purpose
dictionaryExamples: The book is intended for anyone who wants to learn more about the Internet.
The course is intended for intermediate-level students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are various pieces of software intended for off-line use on the market. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: extreme or very strong
dictionaryExamples: intense heat/pain
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Most of the rooms we stayed in did not have air-condition[ing], which caused many sleepless nights [for] the majority of us due to the intense heat. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: Intense people are very serious, and usually have strong emotions or opinions.
dictionaryExamples: He's always been very intense.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I admire people with heart and soul, with that real charisma which can only blossom in highly intelligent and spiritual people - this is what we call 'intense personality'. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: extremely
dictionaryExamples: Her book is intensely personal.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The sky was intensely blue. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: with strong, serious emotions
dictionaryExamples: She stared at me intensely.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She wanted so intensely that her wish should be fulfilled. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: fully, or with great concentration, effort, or attention
dictionaryExamples: He focused intensely on the sheet of music before him.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She looked more intensely at her reflection and suddenly realized that it really did not matter whether or not a friend of hers found her diary. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

sense.def: to become greater, more serious, or more extreme, or to make something do this
dictionaryExamples: The fighting has intensified in the last two weeks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This feeling is intensified when the relationship between Jack and Ralph develops to antagonism. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: the quality of being felt strongly or having a very strong effect
dictionaryExamples: the intensity of the blaze
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As soon as a ray of light reaches the inside of the seashell, it sparkles with an intensity that nearly hurts your eye. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: involving a lot of effort or activity in a short period of time
dictionaryExamples: two weeks of intensive training
an intensive course in English
Intensive bombing had reduced the city to rubble.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am 23 years old and speak English fluently due to my intensive study of the language. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: in way that involves a lot of work in a short period of time
dictionaryExamples: I spent three weeks working intensively on my thesis.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: Grammar, listening and writing were taught adequately, but less intensively than speaking. 
 Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: when you want and plan to do something
dictionaryExamples: It had not been his intent to hurt anyone.
sense.learnerExample:
Learner example: I would suggest some recommendations on how to improve the service of this library with the intent of attracting more people. 
 Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: in all the most important ways
dictionaryExamples: To all intents and purposes, the project was a disaster.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To all intents and purposes, the qualities needed to achieve success are based on the same ideas. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to be determined to do or achieve something
dictionaryExamples: She seems intent on winning this year's tennis tournament.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a venue intent on showing alternative music. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: something that you want and plan to do
dictionaryExamples: It wasn't my intention to exclude her from the list - I just forgot her.
I've no intention of changing my plans just to fit in with his.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I was very pleased [to] hear from your club, because it was always my intention to join such a group and make music with other people. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to talk and do things with other people
dictionaryExamples: At school, teachers said he interacted well with other students.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: People say that when you use a computer you get addicted and don't interact with people. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the activity of talking and doing things with other people, or the way you do this
dictionaryExamples: Our work involves a lot of interaction with the customers.
