sense.def: Interactive computer games, programs, etc. involve the user by reacting to the way they use them.
dictionaryExamples: an interactive game
This is an interactive museum where children can actively manipulate the exhibits.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In addition, you can play with several interactive game[s] and learn about the rules of the Olympic Games. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: involving communication between people
dictionaryExamples: interactive teaching methods
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But I hope you don't mind me sugg[e]sting that you should try do th[ese] talks in smaller groups, so they'll become more interactive and even more interesting. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Czech

sense.def: the feeling of wanting to give your attention to something or of wanting to discover more about it
dictionaryExamples: I've always had an interest in astronomy.

I lost interest halfway through the movie.
She takes more of an interest in politics these days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Well, really I don't have much interest in clothes. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: something  that you enjoy doing, studying or experiencing
dictionaryExamples: On his form he lists his interests as cycling, the cinema and cooking.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In your next letter tell me about your hobbies and interests. Preliminary English Test; B1; Russian

sense.def: the quality that makes you think that something is interesting
dictionaryExamples:
Nothing much of interest was
 
 discussed.
Would this book be of any interest to you?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We visited the Eiffel Tower and lots of other places of interest. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: money which is charged by a bank or other financial organization for borrowing money
dictionaryExamples: Interest charges on credit cards  are can be very high.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Extremely high interest rates and high unemployment were a fatal combination for many families. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: money that you earn from keeping your money in an account in a bank or other financial organization
dictionaryExamples: You should put the money in a savings account where it will earn interest.

sense.def: to help someone and give them an advantage
dictionaryExamples: It may not be in your interest to change jobs so soon.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is in my interests to meet new people and I find it easy to go and talk to people I do not know. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Danish

sense.def: in order to achieve a particular situation or quality
dictionaryExamples: In the interest of safety, passengers are advised to wear their seat belts at all times.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: First of all, do make sure that the front door is always locked. In the interests of everybody's security, it is essential to remember [this]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: something that gives someone or something an advantage
dictionaryExamples: A union looks after the interests of its members.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I realize that you are trying to serve your customers the best way you can, but you might want to consider the interests of the people who live in this area. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: a situation where someone cannot make fair decisions because they are influenced by something
dictionaryExamples: She resigned from the committee because of a conflict of interest.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It could become a conflict of interest, but he never lets it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: If someone or something interests you, you want to give them your attention and discover more about them.
dictionaryExamples: Sports have never really interested me.

sense.def: wanting to give your attention to something and discover more about it
dictionaryExamples: He didn't seem very interested in what I was saying.
I'd be interested to hear more about your work.
"Really?" he said, with an interested look on his face.
Yes, I'd be very interested in knowing more about the services your company offers.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm very interested in sports. Key English Test; A2; Chinese

sense.def: Someone or something that is interesting keeps your attention because they are unusual, exciting, or have a lot of ideas.
dictionaryExamples: She's quite an interesting woman.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like reading interesting books in [the] Library. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def:
used to introduce information that you think is
 
 surprising and interesting
dictionaryExamples:
Interestingly, he never
 
 actually said that he was innocent.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Russians today prefer fast food due to a rapid lifestyle. Interestingly, this refers only to lunch time; about 80% of Russians will prefer eating [a] traditional Russian meal for dinner. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Russian

sense.def: to try to control or become involved in a situation, in a way that is annoying
dictionaryExamples: I know he's worried about us, but I wish he wouldn't interfere.
You shouldn't interfere in other people's business.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I would like to stress that very often famous people become reserved, bad-tempered and angry with the world for interfering in their lives. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to prevent something from working effectively or from developing successfully
dictionaryExamples: I try not to let my dancing classes interfere with my schoolwork.

dictionaryExamples: There have been claims of too much political interference in education.

dictionaryExamples: Your computer is causing interference - when you turned it on the radio started buzzing.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As for the latter, when low flying aircraft are approaching or overflying we are not able to hear or watch anything because these aircraft cause a lot of interference and distortion. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Maltese

sense.def: temporary and intended to be used or accepted until something permanent exists
dictionaryExamples: an interim solution
an interim government

sense.def: the inside part of something
dictionaryExamples: The real estate agent had pictures of the house from the outside but none of its interior.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The interior is quite modern and clean. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: between the highest and lowest levels of knowledge or skill
dictionaryExamples: There are three levels of difficulty in this game: low, intermediate and high.
This novel is too difficult for intermediate students of English.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My level is intermediate. Preliminary English Test; B1; Japanese

sense.def: a short period of time between the parts of a play, performance, etc.
dictionaryExamples: The show "Zorro" had only one intermission of 20 minutes.

sense.def: existing or happening inside a person, object, organization, place or country
dictionaryExamples: He sustained injuries to his arms, legs and several internal organs.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She met [with] an accident and this damaged her internal organs. Preliminary English Test; B1; Chinese

sense.def: inside a person, object, organization, place or country
dictionaryExamples: This medicine is for external use only and should not be taken internally.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I am actually very interested in taking the course, because recently I have change[d] my job and one of my functions is to create a page on the intranet to share information about the company internally. International English Language Testing System; C1; Spanish

sense.def: relating to or involving two or more countries
dictionaryExamples: international politics
an international team of scientists
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Go to the international museum, it's wonderful. Key English Test; A2; Arabic

sense.def: in many countries
dictionaryExamples: Her internationally acclaimed novel has won several literary prizes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This film was directed by Yasujino-Ozo, who is internationally famous, although his film is very Japanese. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

dictionaryExamples: I found out about the book on the Internet.
a company that provides cheap Internet access
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She uses the Internet every day. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Hungarian

sense.def: to change what someone has said into a different language
dictionaryExamples: We had to ask the guide to interpret for us.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My boss decided it [wa]s high time I tried to interpret for him outside our office. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

dictionaryExamples: It's difficult to interpret these statistics without knowing how they were obtained.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Musicians try to interpret it, but admittedly they will never find the whole meaning of it. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; German

sense.def: an explanation or opinion of what something means
dictionaryExamples: traditional interpretations of the Latin text
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Yet this raises the question of the actual effect travel has on our understanding and interpretation of the world outside our country, as well as on the idea we have of our country itself. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: the way someone performs a particular play, piece of music, etc.
dictionaryExamples: a beautiful interpretation of Swan Lake
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Every time I think of this memorable day, I wish I could thank my host-family over and over again since then - little did I know that I would be accepted at Paris' Conservatory a few months later, thanks to my interpretation of Mozart's concerto! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to stop someone while they are talking or doing something, by saying or doing something yourself
dictionaryExamples: She tried to explain what had happened but he kept interrupting her.

dictionaryExamples: There were so many interruptions, I couldn't get on with my work.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I stayed two or three minutes in the darkness thinking that it was only a [brief] interruption, but it was not the case. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: a period of time between two actions, activities, or events
dictionaryExamples: After an interval of three days, the peace talks resumed.

sense.def: to become involved in a situation in order to try to stop a fight, argument, problem, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Government officials refused to intervene in the recent disputes.

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: While an old cynic like Bismarck might not have approved of intervening in the Balkans, even he should see the point of this. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Danish

dictionaryExamples: Without medical intervention, the child would have died.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I write to seek your intervention in a matter that has seriously impacted on the reputation of your retail business. International English Language Testing System; C2; Yapese

sense.def: a meeting in which someone asks you questions to see if you are suitable for a job or course
dictionaryExamples: a job interview

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have to go [to] a job interview which I'm looking forward [to]. Preliminary English Test; B1; Farsi

sense.def: a meeting in which someone is asked questions about themselves for a newspaper article, television show, etc
dictionaryExamples: an exclusive interview with Paul Simon

sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The column also [has] interviews with a couple of different artists. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

dictionaryExamples: We've had 200 applicants for the job, but we only plan to interview about 20 of them.
Who's the most famous person you've ever interviewed on TV?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We had to interview our partner and to present him to the class. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: private and personal
dictionaryExamples: intimate details of her family life
intimate conversations
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, we have to take into consideration that cultural and educational development opens the path for learning and becoming conscious of our intimate feelings and personality and helps us to become better pe[ople]. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: having a special relationship with someone who you like or love very much
dictionaryExamples: an intimate friend
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, before 5 am the couple leaves the party (in desperate need of [rest]) and so do their intimate friends and family. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: If a place or event is intimate, it is small in a way that feels comfortable or private.
dictionaryExamples: an intimate hotel
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The dining room is small and intimate, allowing a relaxed and personal atmosphere, which is highlighted by the soft, Indian background music and the dimmed lights. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: when you know all of the facts about something or about how it works
dictionaryExamples: He has an intimate knowledge of the area.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact that Sinclair spend[s] most of his weekends hiking is easily understood through his intimate knowledge of wilderness lore, of which tidbits pop up now and then in the text. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: toward the inside or middle of something
dictionaryExamples: He's gone into a  store across the street.
Let's go into the living room.
Stop running around and get into bed!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think I left my watch in the kitchen of your house, before we went into the swimming-pool. Key English Test; A2; Spanish

sense.def: used to show when a person or thing changes from one form or condition to another
dictionaryExamples: Peel the cucumber and chop it into small cubes.
Her novels have been translated into nineteen languages.
We're planning to turn the smallest bedroom into an office.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like it very much because now I can convert any  language into Bengali. Key English Test; A2; Bengali

sense.def: moving toward something or someone and hitting them
dictionaryExamples: He's always walking into things when he doesn't have his glasses on.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then I bumped into a man... What a surprise! [It] was Thom Yorke. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: in the direction of something or someone
dictionaryExamples: She was looking straight into his eyes.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After we ate Peter looked into my eyes and said: "Sarah I love you", and he kissed me. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to be very interested in something
dictionaryExamples: Will's really into jazz.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You see, the countryside is good for vacation, but I'm not so into it that I would like to live there! Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: too bad or unpleasant to deal with or accept
dictionaryExamples: an intolerable situation
The constant fighting made life at home intolerable.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The situation has become absolutely intolerable. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swedish

sense.def: when someone is intolerant
dictionaryExamples: He spoke out against racism and intolerance.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The process of mutual understanding that emerges from this contact can help solv[e] one of the greatest problems facing mankind, the ethnic, racial or religious intolerance that plagues different parts of the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: refusing to accept any opinions, beliefs, customs, etc., that are different from your own
dictionaryExamples: She can be very intolerant of other people's opinions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Right now, tolerance and understanding come very natural[ly] to me, in contrast with the narrow-minded, intolerant attitude I [had] to share when I had hardly ever gone beyond the limits of my home town. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: An intransitive verb does not have an object.
dictionaryExamples: In the sentence '"I tried to persuade him, but he wouldn't come'", "come" is an intransitive verb.
In the Wordlist, verbs which are intransitive are marked [I].

sense.def: very interesting
dictionaryExamples: an intriguing story
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Only a minority of our citizens make regular use of the library, either by enjoying a quiet few minutes to scour the bookshel[ve]s for an intriguing story to keep them going through the next rainy weekend or by reading one of the numerous newspapers on display. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: An intrinsic quality or thing forms part of the basic character of something or someone.
dictionaryExamples: Drama is an intrinsic part of the school curriculum.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Working is an intrinsic part of human nature, without which life may be unthinkable for some of us. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: to tell someone another person's name the first time that they meet
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to introduce my younger son, Mark.
Have you two been introduced (to each other)?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We were introduced to each other and we talked about our home countries. Preliminary English Test; B1; Slovak

sense.def: to make something exist, happen or be used for the first time
dictionaryExamples: Ice skating, as an Olympic competition, was introduced in 1908.
We have introduced a new training schedule for employees.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Mr. Dixon, you and your staff have already introduced a number of alterations that have improved the interior of the building. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to tell an audience who is going to speak to them or perform for them
dictionaryExamples: I'd like to introduce Rachel Elliott who is our speaker this evening.

sense.def: the action of telling someone another person's name the first time that they meet
dictionaryExamples: You'll have to do/make the introductions - I don't know everyone's name.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As we didn't know each other, the meeting started with the introduction of everybody. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the opening text of a book, speech, article, etc.
dictionaryExamples: Read the introduction to the article and decide what it will be about.
The book has an introduction by Antonia Byatt.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Report introduction: The purpose to this report is to give suggestion[s] [of] how to make the reception [area] more welcoming for everyone. First Certificate in English; B2; Swedish

sense.def: when you make something exist, happen or be used for the first time
dictionaryExamples: The introduction of new working practices has dramatically improved productivity.
Within a few years of their introduction, CDs were outselling vinyl records.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: With the introduction of the computer, we can [now] access [the] Internet to communicate with our relatives and friends living abroad. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a book or course which provides basic knowledge about a subject
dictionaryExamples: an introduction to psychology
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Please send me some information about your club and tell me about courses like "[an] introduction to flying". First Certificate in English; B2; Pass

sense.def: the first time someone experiences something
dictionaryExamples: It was our first introduction to great poetry.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In 1998 it was the first introduction to home internet access and as we can see from the chart, less than 10% of people had one at home. Skills for Life (Level 2); C1; Polish

sense.def: someone who is quiet and shy and prefers to be alone
dictionaryExamples: He's quite an introvert.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As an introvert, he had some problems with airing his opinions but when it came to competing with others he was the best. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: to become involved in a situation which people want to be private
dictionaryExamples: I don't mean to intrude, but are you okay?

He was fed up with the media intruding into his life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The fact is that raising a child is a strictly personal matter and also a demanding task nowadays and no one can intrude on a family's privacy, to influence its decision. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: someone who enters a place where they are not allowed to be, often to commit a crime
dictionaryExamples: I heard intruders at the back of the house.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The Police Department did accept that the Jouzalez house was not robbed, but only showed signs of mess and disorder, as if the intruders were looking for something specific, for [a] certain document. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: someone who goes to a place or  becomes involved in a situation where others do not want them
dictionaryExamples: I felt like an intruder at their dinner table.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hooper considered the newcomer to be an intruder, to be subtly persecuted. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Russian

sense.def: when someone becomes involved in a situation which people want to be private
dictionaryExamples: She could not bear the intrusion into her private life.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Agatha lay underneath her covers dreading the moment when some intrusion m[ight] force her to leave the sanctuary of her four-poster bed. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: the feeling that you know something without being able to explain why
dictionaryExamples: Her approach to childcare is based on intuition.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: But Roger had repeatedly told Lindsay that he was innocent, and her intuition told her that he wasn't lying. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to enter a country by force in order to take control of it
dictionaryExamples: Concentrations of troops near the border look set to invade within the next few days.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Hitler invaded France. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to enter a place in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: Every summer the town is invaded by tourists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As tourists invade us in large hoards, the menace of destroying the green values of our land appears. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Farsi

sense.def: to try to learn things about someone's private life when they do not want you to
dictionaryExamples: They were fed up with journalists invading their privacy.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: He would never invade our privacy or force us to talk about our problems. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to become a part of someone's life without them asking for or wanting the involvement
dictionaryExamples: Computers are invading our lives.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The biggest one, the computer, has invaded our life and changed the whole rhythm. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: extremely useful
dictionaryExamples: Her contacts proved invaluable to the company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: These materials will be an invaluable source of information for our students. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: always
dictionaryExamples: The train is invariably packed.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Nevertheless, there is invariably an exception to the rule. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: when an army enters a country by force in order to take control of it
dictionaryExamples: They were planning to mount an invasion of the north of the country.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Then, we went to the North of D[e]nmark to see what remains of [the] Viking invasions. First Certificate in English; B2; French

sense.def: becoming involved in someone's private life when they do not want you to
dictionaryExamples: These phone calls to my home are an invasion of my privacy.

sense.def: when people enter a place in large numbers
dictionaryExamples: Every year, there is an invasion of tourists.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The invasion of tourists seems to take away some of the place's privacy and it can even destroy its usually peaceful environment.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: to design or create something which has never existed before
dictionaryExamples: The first safety razor was invented by company founder King C. Gillette in 1903.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lots of different and important things were invented during the 20th century, [but]  I believe that the most important one is the computer. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: to think of a story or explanation in order  to deceive someone
dictionaryExamples: But I didn't invent the story - everything I told you is true.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We knew that our parents wouldn't let us travel alone so we had to invent a story to avoid [them realizing] what happened. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something which has been designed or created for the first time, or the act of creating or designing something
dictionaryExamples: The world changed rapidly after the invention of the telephone.
a most amazing invention
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I think that the television is one of the most amazing inventions ever. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: someone who designs and makes new things
dictionaryExamples: He was the inventor of the vacuum cleaner.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thomas Al[v]a Eddison []is probably the greatest inventor of all time with [1093] patents. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to give money to a bank, business, etc., or buy something, because you hope to get a profit
dictionaryExamples: The institute will invest 5 million in the project.
He's not certain whether to invest in the real estate market.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: However, you could invest the extra money in the infrastructure. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: to use a lot of time, effort, or emotions because you want to succeed
dictionaryExamples: You have all invested significant amounts of time and energy in making this project the success that it is.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: So, investing a bit of time and care on you[rself] might be the reason for your 90th birthday party! First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: to try to discover all the facts about something, especially a crime or accident
dictionaryExamples: Police are investigating allegations of corruption involving senior executives.
We are of course investigating how an error like this could have occurred.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: John, who was the husband of Julia, went to his office and started investigating the kidnapping. First Certificate in English; B2; Greek

sense.def: when officials try to discover all the facts about something, especially a crime or an accident
dictionaryExamples: to carry out/hold an investigation
An investigation has been under way for several days into the disappearance of a thirteen-year-old boy.
a full/thorough investigation of the incident
Currently, the individuals who might have caused the accident are subject to/under investigation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: After a month[-long] investigation of the environment, I found we still don't do enough to protect the environment. First Certificate in English; B2; Chinese

sense.def: a person whose job is to examine a crime, accident, etc. in order to discover the truth
dictionaryExamples: Investigators have studied the possible effects of contamination.
a private investigator
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: My name is Jacques Martinov, and I am a private investigator. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: the money that you put in a bank, business, etc. in order to make a profit, or the act of doing this
dictionaryExamples: Stocks are regarded as good long-term investments.
The account requires a minimum investment of $1000.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, [i]f I want to organize my investments, I can use a suitable computer program for it. First Certificate in English; B2; Spanish

sense.def: something that you do or have, in order to have more in the future
dictionaryExamples: Going to college is an investment in the future.
There's been a significant investment of time and energy in order to make the project a success.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Of course I was able to purchase a second-hand one but I thought that it was a good investment to have a new computer provided with up-to-date software. First Certificate in English; B2; Russian

sense.def: a person who puts money into a bank, business, etc.  in order to make a profit
dictionaryExamples: A New York investor offered to acquire the company's stock for $13 a share.
Small investors  are hoping that the markets will improve.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This should be done by lowering taxes and preparing other incentives for potential investors. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: impossible to see
dictionaryExamples: The aircraft is designed to be invisible to radar.
The house was invisible from the road.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: [At] that moment I really wished I could disap[p]ear or become invisible! First Certificate in English; B2; Dutch

sense.def: when someone invites you to do something or go somewhere
dictionaryExamples: Thanks for the invitation to your birthday party.
I'm happy to accept your invitation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Thank you for your invitation. Key English Test; A2; Catalan

sense.def: something that is likely to cause a particular result, especially a bad one
dictionaryExamples:
Leaving your house unlocked
 is an open invitation to burglars.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This was hard to resist for computer programmers wh[o] understood it as an invitation to try and fool the examiner with a cunning computer program. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: to ask someone to come to a social event or to spend time with you socially
dictionaryExamples: We're invited to Lola's party.
Her family invited me to stay with them for a few weeks.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm really happy you invited me for dinner. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Polish

sense.def: to ask someone to do something in a formal or official way
dictionaryExamples: I was invited to appear on television.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: We invite your newspaper to reconsider its position, hoping that the council will think about our proposals. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Spanish

sense.def: to do something that is likely to cause a particular reaction or result, especially a bad one
dictionaryExamples: Unconventional ideas often invite attack/criticism.

sense.def: If a situation or activity involves something, that thing is a necessary part of it.
dictionaryExamples: The trips often involve a lot of walking.
The course involves a huge amount of reading.
There are a lot of risks involved.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is a competition for school[s] and it involves many kinds of sport. Preliminary English Test; B1; Portuguese

sense.def: to affect or include someone or something in an activity
dictionaryExamples: The second accident involved two cars and a truck.
It would be difficult not to involve the child's father in the arrangements.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: She had writ[t]en me to tell me that our friends Todd and Alice had died in an strange accident that involved a vacu[u]m cleaner. Preliminary English Test; B1; Spanish

sense.def: to make someone be part of an activity or process
dictionaryExamples: I prefer teaching methods that actively involve students in learning.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Trying to involve children and young people in general, interactive activities could be really successful. First Certificate in English; B2; Italian

sense.def: when someone or something is involved in an activity or event
dictionaryExamples: The team's continued involvement in the competition is uncertain.
He denies any involvement in the attack.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: By reading we get a sort of personal involvement with the characters, it's [as] if it was our own story. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: a dark grey metal used to make steel and found in very small amounts in blood and food
dictionaryExamples: an iron bar
Iron rusts easily.
Liver is a particularly rich source of iron.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It wasn't very expensive because it was made of iron without any decoration, but it was important because she gave it to me before she died. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: a piece of electrical equipment that you use for making clothes flat and smooth
dictionaryExamples: a steam iron
a travel iron
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For example, are there any people who want to buy an iron at midnight? First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to make clothes flat and smooth using an iron
dictionaryExamples: I need to iron a shirt to wear tomorrow.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I like wearing jeans because the[y] are very co[m]fortable, and are also easy to wash and to iron. Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: An ironic situation is strange because it is the opposite of what you would expect.
dictionaryExamples: It's ironic that she was hurt by the very person she's trying to help.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: As I used my stealth to move through the shadows, I thought it ironic that the rich man's expensive and probably imported carpets should assist me in keeping quiet. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Chinese

sense.def: used to emphasize that a situation is strange because it is the opposite of what you expected
dictionaryExamples: Ironically, the only good book on this subject has gone out of print.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Either way, food is a big industry and a vital contributor to our culture, but ironically, food is also the biggest problem in the world. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Japanese

sense.def: the activity of making clothes flat and smooth, using an iron
dictionaryExamples: I must do some ironing tonight.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: And I would like to do a little bit of work in your household like washing clothes, ironing and so on. First Certificate in English; B2; German

sense.def: a situation that is strange because it is the opposite of what you expected
dictionaryExamples: The irony is now that he's retired, he's busier than ever.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The irony of all [this] is the fact that she lives in the same house with Kingshaw and Hooper and she keeps being unable to notice what is really going on till the very end. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Greek

sense.def: a type of humor in which people say the opposite of what they really mean
dictionaryExamples: There is a lot of irony in his writing.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: His strength l[ie]s in drawing exact pictures of the human mind by using extraordinary metaphors and idioms and describing our society with his never-ending tone of sarcasm and irony. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: Irrational feelings and actions are based on your emotions and not on good reasons.
dictionaryExamples: irrational behavior
an irrational fear of flying
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It was an irrational fear, but try to explain this to a five-year-old girl who constantly dreamt about vampire dolls killing her while she was unable to move! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Romanian

sense.def: In grammar, an irregular verb, noun, adjective, etc. does not obey the usual rules for words in the language.
dictionaryExamples: a table of irregular verbs

sense.def: Irregular actions or events happen with a different amount of time between each one.
dictionaryExamples: They met at irregular intervals.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To make matters worse, the meal times are irregular, so as a result I am skinny. First Certificate in English; B2; Korean

sense.def: not smooth or straight, or having parts that are different sizes
dictionaryExamples: an irregular coastline
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In my hurry, I never saw the irregular floor and I fell [over]! First Certificate in English; B2; Catalan

sense.def: extremely attractive and impossible not to like or want
dictionaryExamples: an irresistible smile
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: For instance, a perfume might make men irresistible to women, or vice versa. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Swiss German

sense.def: too powerful to control or ignore
dictionaryExamples: irresistible pressure
an irresistible desire to run away
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: From time to time we do feel an irresistible desire to get possession of something that is not a must. We are so tempted that we buy it. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Polish

sense.def: not thinking about the possible bad results of what you are doing
dictionaryExamples: irresponsible behavior
Leaving the door unlocked was irresponsible!
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You can't alway[s] rely on the drivers, who are sometimes irresponsible and careless. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: Something that is irreversible cannot be changed back to how it was before.
dictionaryExamples: irreversible damage to the heart/lungs

Technology has had an irreversible
 
 impact on society.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It is important to remember that everything done excessively can have irreversible consequences! Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; German

sense.def: becoming annoyed very easily
dictionaryExamples: Jack's been irritable all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Lord Trimingham remains calm throughout the story whereas Ted Burgess se[e]ms quite irritable and impulsive. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; French

sense.def: to annoy someone
dictionaryExamples: His comments really irritated me.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Children get h[y]peractive and irritate other passengers. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Portuguese

sense.def: annoyed
dictionaryExamples: Ben began to get increasingly irritated by/with her questions.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Tom noticed that she was irritated about something. First Certificate in English; B2; Turkish

sense.def: making you feel annoyed
dictionaryExamples: an irritating habit
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, like all things in life, shopping can be pleas[a]nt or irritating depending on your patience and on your mood that day. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese

sense.def: the feeling of being annoyed, or something that makes you annoyed
dictionaryExamples:
minor
 irritations
That kind of behavior is sure to cause irritation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In the daytime, the noise leads to irritation. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a piece of land completely surrounded by water
dictionaryExamples: a desert island
a Pacific island
They live on the large Japanese island of Hokkaido.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I'm on the island [of] Aruba. Key English Test; A2; Russian

sense.def: a long way from other places
dictionaryExamples: an isolated village in the mountains
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You might get lost in an isolated region without anyone to help you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Romanian

sense.def: alone and not having help or support from other people
dictionaryExamples: Kazuo felt very isolated at his new school.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Before you even know it, you'll feel isolated and alone because other people will have forgotten about you. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Greek

sense.def: a case/event/example, etc. that happens only once
dictionaryExamples: This robbery was not an isolated incident.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is just an isolated example among an endless list. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Portuguese

sense.def: the state of being separate from other people, places, or things
dictionaryExamples: the country's economic isolation from the rest of the world
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Due to the isolation, the country had to feed itself with everything which was needed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Catalan

sense.def: alone, or separately from other people, places, or things
dictionaryExamples: These poems cannot be considered in isolation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: In conclusion, it is my opinion that the problem of parking space cannot be solved in isolation. International English Language Testing System; C2; Afrikaans

sense.def: a feeling of being lonely
dictionaryExamples: I had this awful sense of isolation.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Unemployment can lead to isolation.  Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: a subject or problem which people are thinking and talking about
dictionaryExamples: environmental/moral/personal issues
As employers we need to be seen to be addressing these issues sympathetically.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: You're a student so this should be a very important issue for you. Preliminary English Test; B1; Lithuanian

sense.def: the newspaper, magazine, etc. that is produced on a particular day/week/month
dictionaryExamples: Have you seen the latest issue of Computer World?
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Having seen your advertisement in the 4th issue of Asahi News, I hasten to write this letter. First Certificate in English; B2; Japanese

sense.def: to disagree with what someone says or writes
dictionaryExamples:
Isn’t the need to hire more staff
 
 what’s really at issue here.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On behalf of the staff who worked for this event, I would like to take issue with the report's inaccuracies and unfair remarks. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Japanese

sense.def: most important in what is being discussed
dictionaryExamples: The point at issue is what is best for the child.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I wouldn't like to fall into the trap of generalizing the matter at issue, but I believe there are two ways of traveling. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Italian

sense.def: to officially say something or give someone something
dictionaryExamples: The office will be issuing parking permits on Tuesday and Thursday mornings.
The fire department issued a statement about its plans.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, the doctors issued an ultimatum. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Dutch

sense.def: information technology: the use of computers and other electronic equipment to store and send information
dictionaryExamples: He's a project manager for a large IT company.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I want to study I.T. because it is very useful. Skills for Life (Entry 2); A2; Cantonese

sense.def: used to refer to the thing, situation, or idea that has already been talked about
dictionaryExamples: "Where's my pen?" "You left it by the phone."
The argument was upsetting for us all - I don't want to talk about it.
Children who stay away from school do it for different reasons.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: This is a very beautiful place and I like it. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Urdu

sense.def: used as the subject or object of a verb to represent a phrase at the end of the sentence
dictionaryExamples: I liked it in Scotland.
It's unlikely that she'll arrive on time.
It costs less if you travel at the weekend.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It's [a] nice place. Skills for Life (Entry 1); A1; Italian

sense.def: used to talk about the time, date, weather or distances
dictionaryExamples: What time is it?
It was October, so it was quite cold.
It rained all day.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It rained and rained and rained and it really didn't want to stop raining. Preliminary English Test; B1; German

sense.def: used as the subject of verbs such as "seem," "appear," and "look"
dictionaryExamples: It seemed unfair to leave her at home.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: It seemed fantastic but we knew our parents would never agree. First Certificate in English; B2; Polish

sense.def: used to say the name of a person or thing when the person you are speaking to does not know
dictionaryExamples: It's your Dad on the phone.

sense.def: used to emphasize one part of a sentence
dictionaryExamples: It's the children I'm concerned about, not me.

sense.def: If a part of your body itches, it feels uncomfortable and you want to rub it with your nails.
dictionaryExamples: Woollen sweaters make my arms itch.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: On the other hand I loathe jumpers since they make me itch, so I buy them once in a blue moon! Preliminary English Test; B1; Italian

sense.def: to want to do something very much
dictionaryExamples: You could tell that they were itching to leave.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: The difference between these two kinds of people lies exactly there: the package-tourist is itching to go back home [as soon as] he sets off whereas the traveler may never go back home. Certificate of Proficiency in English; C2; Spanish

sense.def: a single thing in a set or on a list
dictionaryExamples: the last item on the list
The restaurant has a long menu of about 50 items.
Several items of clothing lay on the floor.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: I have tasted all the items in that restaurant. Preliminary English Test; B1; Bengali

sense.def: a piece of news on television or radio, or in a newspaper
dictionaryExamples: a small item on the back page of the local newspaper
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Last week, in the "East London Journal", I read an item about your opening an Investor Club. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: a list of places that you plan to visit on a journey
dictionaryExamples: The President's itinerary includes visits to Boston and New York.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: Finally, although the itinerary involved a visit to St. Andrews, for some unknown reasons we never went there and I was really disappointed. Certificate in Advanced English; C1; Italian

sense.def: belonging to or relating to something that has already been mentioned
dictionaryExamples: The dog hurt its paw.
Their house has its own swimming pool.
The company increased its profits.
I prefer the second option - its advantages are simplicity and cheapness.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: When you touch it, a light bulb appears on its screen. Key English Test; A2; Turkish

sense.def: the reflexive form of the pronoun "it"
dictionaryExamples: The cat licked itself all over.

sense.def: alone or without help
dictionaryExamples: The dog was in the house by itself for several days.
The dog managed to drag the box into the room by itself.
I didn't take any medicine for the cough - it just  got better itself.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: If an animal is kept by itself, with no-one to keep it company, it [gets] lonely and very sad. First Certificate in English; B2; Danish

sense.def: used to put emphasis on a word
dictionaryExamples: The shop itself started 15 years ago but the mail-order side of the business is new.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: There are lots of trees and bushes,  but the city itself is quite ugly. Preliminary English Test; B1; Romanian

sense.def: used emphasize that something is true of one particular thing but that other things may have to be considered
dictionaryExamples: The plan wasn't illegal in itself but it would lead to some doubtful practices.
sense.learnerExample: Learner example: To begin with, a car, in my opinion, can't be harmful in itself. First Certificate in English; B2; Portuguese
